content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												This game is a lot of fun. It is definitely best played with a group of friends which you can converse with. To be entirely honest, it is not that great if you play against the AI. The AI has this ability to screw themselves in ways that are entirely possible to avoid with a little bit of thought. For instance, the AI will use an axe to get across the river only to cross back to the outer area the next turn.I would highly recommend this to people which enjoy tabletop games which contain both an element of strategy and an element of luck. There is a lot in this game which requires luck, but once you have played a few games, you can get a feel of what the better spaces and strategies are. Playing with random characters also forces you to get used to new ways of playing the game, making each game much different from the last.Keep in mind, a single string of bad luck can pretty much end your run in the game or force you to play catch up for the remainder of the game if everyone else is doing well.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												I like board games. Talisman is a decent board game. And while this game models the board game fairly well, there is one critical issue and several other annoyances.The critical issue is that the dice roll is not randomised. To demonstrate, perform a turn to see how the die rolls, exit, reload, and then re-do your turn to see the dice roll the exact same way. I've performed different actions and even seen the AI players get the dice rolls I would have got. It's ridiculous. The whole point of rolling a dice is to be random. Not random = not a dice roll.The annoyances are as previously alerted to in prior reviews, mostly to do with poor AI, but I could have lived with that had the dice rolls actually been pseudo-random, you know, ceiling(math.rand()*6) or something.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												Do not pay full purchase for this game.I havn't played Talisman before, so take that in mind.The interface is slow and clumsy. It takes 3 seconds for anything you click to work. Looking at an inventory can be a challenge in itself.You can't look at the spaces outside of your turns, and when you do, it takes ages again. You can't just scroll over it, you have to right-click it, wait, right-click it again, wait and then right-click a card you might want to check on it.The timing of spell cards and everything is thrown out the window, because the clicking responses are very, very slow.And that isn't getting to the bugs.Out for the 4 games I have played so far, each single one has been wrecked because of the terrible interface and bugs.Game one, I choose an apprentice wizard. Get to one life, and look at one of my spells waiting for my turn.Turn comes up, the spell casts itself. And I die to a miscast.Game two, I get a courtesan. I go to flirt with an orc, and take his useful follower, giving me a massive lead. Instead, after looking at his inventory, as I back out, it decided to take me backing out of his inventory as a challenge to combat. Instead of taking something, I then enter physical combat, whith my 2 against his 5 bonus. I lose. He then takes my magical bag of holding, a bag that says on the card 'This card can not be taken in combat', which contained every single bit of my loot.I'm just happy I got this with Humble Bundle, but I won't get my 5 hours back.That said, I now want to play the physical board game. Since that is more social, faster (yes, this game is faster to play physically) and has no bugs.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I'm actually old enough to own the original board game, which, I absolutely love! I spent many, many hours as a kid beating... I mean, "questing" with my friends. We'd all be sitting on the carpet in the living room, game pieces scattered thither, huddled around the game board as if we were spying into one our dads' Playboy magazines trying not to get caught. Tensions ran high as we traversed the outer ring of the board (or Outer Earth as we called it) in search of glorious adventure and immense wealth. Eventually, one friend would amusingly decide to try to kill off another; starting a great fued betwixt families, and a furious battle would ensue. With every roll of the dice, the once trusting and playful comrades, would try to land on each others spaces to chip off yet another foe's life. All in the hopes of being the last warrior standing... until of coarse... the final blow was struck... the fallen combatant, silent in his shame, with head hung low, would sit and let the anger of defeat fester like a boil. As the heckling and laughter of his friends grew louder, ringing in his ears, becoming too much to bear, the conquered warrior would growl in rage! Leaping up from the game and running away like the wind. Totally♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ He'd jump upon his iron steed, and peddle off into the night, cursing us. Claiming he would never play with us... ever... again.But... we knew he'd be back. Now that I'm a grown-up (or at least supposed to be), this digital version still lets me enjoy beating... I mean "questing" with my friends, even though we're scattered across the globe. It's awesome. And. it's a perfect game for hanging out with the guys online, having a few beers, and sharing a few laughs.It's a great port of the board game. It's challenging, and the DLC is great. Totally worth the money!

I honestly wonder if they had any playtesting before release.  In addition to the terrible balance issues, the online versions UI is abysmal.  Trying to full screen either gives me a black screen half the time or freezes up.  Casting spells that require any type of timing is almost impossible.  There is no undue button and many commands do not have confirm request.  Do not play this game if you value your time in any way.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												If you enjoy the board game, chances are you'll enjoy this. It's essentially just the board game in video game form, which I personally view as a positive. Now, if you can't get a group of friends together to play, you have the option to play against AI or other players online.  Much like the board game, expansions are purchased separately, so keep that in mind.  But the game does come with options for some popular house rules.  My only complaints are that the interface is a little hard to navigate at first and the game only supports up to 4 players instead of 6, but they aren't huge problems that really hamper the game.  In short, I'd recommend to any Talisman fans out there!

												Review for owners of the physical version of Talisman:This is an awesome digital version of the game, and plays in a fraction of the time since all the rules and book-keeping are done for you.  Spell casting is a little quirky but if you read the tutorial closely and play a few times it's not a problem.Review for people who have never heard of this game:Talisman is a fantasy, D&D-esque themed game.  You are racing/battling your opponents to get to the center of the board to trigger the end game (which could be several different scenarios depending on what expansions you have).Be warned, however. You are playing against the game as much as you are your opponents.  While this game does not lack meaningful decision making, there is a heafty dose of RNG as well.

content:

												Well I wasn't expecting something awesome, but after half hour my interest changed into bitterness. A lots of classes is what I really liked about this game. A different options of game style can keep you even in most boring games for a long period of time. But after I discovered how the dice works the fate of this game was forever sealed for me. You will mostly get 1 to 3 on normal rolls and when you roll 1 next roll will be 4. When you roll 2 next roll wil be 5 and same with 3 and 6. The problem is that mostly your opponent gets those good rolls and until you use fate you are screwed. Besides of the evil dice you get a lot of bugs like getting stuck after spell failure because you press some key on the keyboard and there is nothing you can do except for quiting the game. Your raft won't work, your items and so on ... and I experienced this in about 2 hours ... so you can make a picture.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Pros:- faithfull to the originalCons:- faithfull to the originalYou see where this is going. If you liked the original Talisman, you will like this one. It has a few bugs, but the issues it had at release have mostly been handled with and the game is much more stable. If you have not played the original Talisman, let me tell you a few things about it:1) It is competitive2) It is very random. Lots of dice rolls and most often the player who has the lucky rolls and draws the best cards wins. A solid strategy is in no way a guarantee of sucess - it helps but not that much. 3) It is not fair and the characters are not in any way balancedIf you want a fantasy themed strategy game with balanced chances for eac player, look elsewhere. If you seek an unpredictable, fantasy-themed beer&pretzel game, this is it. Given the random nature and colorfull themes in the game, imho this will be a good game to play with your kids or with a younger sibling. Or just with friends if you want to chill out and not be too serious about it.

content:

												Pros:- it sticks to the original board game (figures and cards)- requires some tactical thinking- nice soundtrack- each game is different!- characters from the additions (AND additions themselves!)- many achievements to accomplishCons:- a bit too much randomness- bugs and crashes (thankfully they still improve this)- not so smart bots- the music becomes repetitive after some timeI'm a big fan of the original board game and I'm not dissapointed. Of course nothing beats the atmosphere of sitting with friends around the table and rolling dice by your own hands but, from the other hand, you can compete with other Talisman lovers from the whole world!9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Do you love boardgames? Do you own boardgames? Do you play them with your friends (hopefully!)? Than this game CAN definatly be for you. But it also depends on how much nostalgia you feel for Talisman. Us boardgamers in general probably wont like this game, it takes a lot of time (can take up to 3 hours), your actions are ALMOST completley random thanks to dicerolling. And you also lose the feeling of moving components around on a board which is a huge part of the enjoyment for this game. If you're a not a boardgamer I would recomend that you stay away from this game. It probably wont meet up with any (if any) of your expectations. This game can be fun with a few friends but you will probably end up only playing a single game of it before moving on to some other game or you know... any other REAL boardgame. Talisman in general is sadly not a great boardgame nomatter how much nostalgia you feel for it. It's basicly a more nerdy version of Monopoly which is the worst... boardgame... ever. Instead of getting this get the game for your pads so that you can play it on long trips on a buss, train, car (unless you're driving) and plane. But make sure you have some people to play with even then./ Nurgleprobe

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I used to play this game often with my old roomates twenty years ago. This is an amazing adaptation. The graphics are awesome and faithfully reproduce the board. It would really be nice if other board games could make the digital transition like this one. My only real complaint is that the AI seemed like it was cheating since it would regularily get the rolls it needed to win some unlikely battles or land on a coveted card. I found myself using an exploit to get around the questionable rolls but recently it was updated and the exploit no longer works. The new update seems to generate a dice table the same way many other digital dice games do. I got the season pass for this one also and have been loving all the DLC. The Dungeon is pretty cool. If you liked the original board game then this one is a must. Its easy to loose many hours here.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												After other players managed to convince me the constant crashes are due to a recent expansion and the Devs are usually on top of it with fixes, I realised that it was the hand of fate that made me start this game in the middle of utter chaos.Thus, on the basis of the game alone, I give it my thumbs up(changed from negative).Yes, the game itself, when not crashing, is fun. Well, for people with stamina and patience and time for a bit of commitment it is fun,for people that like the intimacy of boardgames it is fun, I do not recommend it for impatient kids that can't sit still for 15 minutes, because fun will not be had.Is it worth the money the expansion sets cost? That is something everyone needs to decide for themselves, in comparison I'd say it's not too steep (although I'm tight enough to have weighed these words before typing them).All in all, (and I'm liking it more every time I play a game without crashing), I give the game a careful 6.7 out of 10.Please take my playing time into account, which isn't very long, check the reviews of those who have been playing it for longer, or you know, take the plunge!Greetings fellow travellores and connaisseurs of Trollplaying games (TPG's)

												Pros:- it sticks to the original board game (figures and cards)- requires some tactical thinking- nice soundtrack- each game is different!- characters from the additions (AND additions themselves!)- many achievements to accomplishCons:- a bit too much randomness- bugs and crashes (thankfully they still improve this)- not so smart bots- the music becomes repetitive after some timeI'm a big fan of the original board game and I'm not dissapointed. Of course nothing beats the atmosphere of sitting with friends around the table and rolling dice by your own hands but, from the other hand, you can compete with other Talisman lovers from the whole world!9/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Awesome game board.  Each tile can be an adventure onto itself, huge variety of cards in the draw deck.  Excellent conversion of boardgame to computer.  Handles excellently with context-aware menus.  Unfortunately, it's all in the service of a frankly boring King of the Hill scenario.  Infinite respawn until someone reaches the center square, permadeath afterwards.  50% chance that if there's only one character in the center square, all other characters take damage.  If there's more  than one character in the center square then the damage-to-all-else effect turns off while they battle it out.  Considering how easy it is to gain life...If Nomad Games Limited had any other games then I would highly recommend checking them out considering the amount of depth and quality shown here - but they don't seem to have any available.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												I want to enjoy this game, I really do, but there are 3 problems:1.  This game is unbalanced, with some characters being clearly better than other characters.  2.  The interface is terrible.  Spells are incredibly difficult to cast correctly with no ability to decide whether you cast the spell or not based on the presumed result.  Once you click the button, a cavalcade of unintended consequences occur just because you cast it in the wrong phase.  3.  You have very little control over the course of the game.  It is a long game of fantasy Monopoly.  You roll die that determine your fate entirely.  It clearly was created at a time where quantity in a game was more important than quality or balance.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Talisman: Digital Edition은 1~6인용 보드게임 Talisman 4판을 Nomad Games Limited에서 PC 및 휴대기기용으로 제작한 1~4인용 게임입니다. 일전에 이에 앞서 유료데모로 내놓는 만행을 벌였던 Talisman: Prologue에 대해서 리뷰( http://etude87.tistory.com/97 )한 적이 있는데 그것의 완성판으로 2014년 2월 26일에 출시되었습니다.PC 이식 및 네트워크 멀티플레이를 지원한다는 장점이 있으나 멍청한 A.I와 기본 구조적 한계 그리고 각종 멀티플레이를 저어하게 만드는 요소들로 인해 Talisman: Digital Edition은 싹수부터 노랗다는 것을 다시 한번 증명했습니다. 타인에게 썩 추천하고 싶지 않습니다만 비교적 저렴한 가격과 휴대용 기기용으로도 많이 나왔으니 친구들과 모여서 보드게임 하고 싶을 때 실물 대신 사용하는 정도로는 쓸모가 있을 것입니다. 더 자세한 내용은 블로그 포스트( http://etude87.tistory.com/179 )를 참고.ps. 최근 시즌패스 내용물 관련해서 차후 추가될 모든 컨텐츠 제공이란 문구를 수정하고 열번째 캐릭터팩을 시즌패스 적용외 물품으로 내놓으면서 커뮤니티 허브에서도 말이 많아진 상태입니다.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Incredibly fun and infuriating at the same time.  Requires more than 1 play through for you to really appreciate the game, and while the game is heavily luck dependant, there is strategy in managing your resources and coming up with plans to try and succeed from almost all points of the game.  You could be 2 turns from being the winner and then fnd yourself turned toad if youve wasted all your resources getting to where you are.  Two good bonuses to the already good game are that1) The bots are very well made and provide an excellent alternative for when you dont have friends to play with or cant find an open game online2) With the exception of the specific character DLC, as long as the host of a game owns a content DLC, players without the DLC can still join and play with the content (they still wont be able to use the DLC characters however)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												My hours in the digital version are small, but don't let that waver your opinion of my opinion of this unforgiving mistress of a game.I went out and bought the physical edition, and have accumulated several expansions because of how much I absolutely adore the abuse this game deals out (aka: I've dropped over $200 on this series alone).The gamestyle is a weird ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ization of Dungeons&Dragons, and Munchkin.  You each have your own character with their own special attributes and abilities... and often try to screw each other over as much as possible to try and reach the Crown of Command.Expansion packs will add different endings to the game.  One being a Black Hole type card, where if you reveal it, you disappear into the void and the game ends for you.  She's a ♥♥♥♥♥, and I love her.Other endings can reward players depending on if you have the most gold by the end, a certain amount of trophies, etc.  Other endings are revealed at the beginning of the game; one expansion has a setting where all of the characters are by default good, and you're working towards a similiar cause.Expansions also bring different playstyles to the game.  Grim Reaper has already been introduced, who you can send after other players if you happen to roll a 1."Blood Moon" will introduce a werewolf, who moves when a 6 is rolled, and is a mirror of old Grimmy.City, Highlands, Dungeon, and Wildlands are all corner expansions which adds to the map itself.The digital version isn't without error.  There are occasional cards, that when played, will crash the game.  This is usually per them being a target card being played when there was nothing to target.  I wish there was a verify system before setting something into play.The Gold Pack is definitely worth it if you're looking into playing the game for a long time, as it includes every expansion available - and they will be released as they're finished by Nomad.  This also includes side character DLC!The way it works (since I couldn't find an answer to this when I bought the game), is that the person with the gold bundle should be hosting.  That way all of the people who join will have access to the content.  BUT, they will not be able to select any of the DLC characters.  They can, however, select random, and have a chance of drawing one (or three depending on house rules).An average game lasts anywhere from 2-5 hours from our experience.

												This is a nice digital rendition of the original boardgame. It is however somewhat limited in how you play cards, and there should really be an option when you cue a card to be played where you get a question if you want to play it or not when a situation triggers where the card can be played. Currently you have to time certain cards very precisely and you'll end up targeting yourself with bad spells and throw away other cards simply because the game is programmed so that if you cue a card you mindlessly play it on whatever is a legal target. content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This game is a giant waste of time. It could have been great but with brain dead AI and the game actively cheating to make you lose to make up for the unimaginably stupid AI it boils down to an extremely boring slog. I even reached the center only for the game to drag on for another two hours as the AI was too dumb to reach the center and fight me while I rolled less than 4 several times in a row interspaced by one or two times rolling high enough to do damage only for the enemy to miraculously roll the exact number to land on a healing spot over and over and over again. The only reason I won is because they managed to damage themselves to the point where I could kill them with 1 lucky roll. I should be paid for having to suffer through that crap. My recommendation stay away setting the money that could be spent on this game on fire would be a more worthwhile investment and this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												This is a game that plays you. It's a dated digital boardgame. I could see how a lot of people like it, especially if they grew up playing it - that whole nostalgia factor, but it is incredibly long between turns and there is no reason to pay attention to what other players are doing. Due to the completely random nature of the game there is no skill needed to play it or become good. After 30 or 40 rounds I was easily the most powerful player and well on my way to winning, but I found myself extremely bored. I even tried to get myself killed, and succeeded, hoping that the game would be over. That just wasn't the case, and I found myself reset at the same point in the game - grinding to get more powerful to further advance inward. I increasingly found myself stepping away from the computer between turns after a couple of rounds. This just isn't for me. It might be more fun with other people, chatting over mics while doing something else more brain intensive. I'd honestly rather just play a better game with friends.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Most buggy game I have ever played. And I have DOSBox.Top 5 bugs and interface fails:1) The spell "Twist of Fate" which should let you choose the outcome of a reroll fails to do anything because the game is ambiguous about when it should be cast.2)  If you have the bag that lets you carry 4 items, you have to reuse it every time you want to add/remove an item!3) No sound indicating it's your turn. You have to stare at the screen for 5 hours because the game's too much of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to let you know it's your turn to act.4) The game throws you out of screens that you're looking at, making it a manic rush to click on your counterspell when an opponent tries to turn you into a toad.5) When a player leaves (ragequits over the terrible interface), the game rewinds about 2 actions. You can choose to follow the previous path (and get the exact same outcome, suggesting that draws and rolls are predetermined), or a new path, in case the old one didn't end up being very lucrative....

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												The game premise is pretty good and I think I would enjoy the actual board game, but as it stands the digital version of the game is somewhat poorly made. I've had numerous glitches occur, and some aspects of the interface are rather annoying. My biggest complaint so far is having played a game as a Ninja the victory condition made it impossible to win. I was required to obtain 2 followers and then discard them in order to complete a Warlock Quest. Ninjas can not have followers. Therefore  I couldn't win. I got a cursed item that made me lose all of my quests, which I used to get rid of that quest and go take a different Warlock quest, to which the game made me take the same quest again, with no roll or anything even though the spot said to roll for it. I did have some irratations with the interface, but those could be avoided once a player becomes familiar with the game. The games been out long enough that really big glitches like this should probably have been patched out. Theres also very squirly things with the NPC players where they will often drag on their turns for a while picking up every single item on a square, and then put every item back down because they lack inventory space, even though they won't take any of the actual items. I could go on, but I got the game for a steal so I can't complain too much. Thinking im going to go buy the board game now though. I rather like the actual game.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												Having played this game a few times now, I've so far encountered: an idiotic AI that doesn't attempt to reach the crown of command, required to win the game, despite having near-max stats.  An AI that will move a single space every turn due to a poltergeist, healing each turn and therefore causing a stalemate, causing me to lose out on XP and achievement progress.  And most recently, an AI that on the brink of a loss decides to constantly check his inventory on an infinite loop, disallowing me my final turn like the worst of poor losers.  Having experienced all this with just 4.7 hours on record shows what a terrible game this is, in terms of AI, bugs, and problems with the game system in general.May still try the online mode as friends have bought the game, but if playing against the AI just give up now.  Either you won't be allowed to win, or it will be a hollow victory.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Sadly this game is NOT worth playing.  Its a great Idea and could have been a lot of fun.  I played a full round against the ai a round with players and a mixed round.Pros:Great IdeaLooks cool.I love board games.It has some really interesting abilities and cards.Cons:The AI is HORRIBLE!  Turns take far to long even at speed 10.Horrible Networking, I couldn't see games and had to have my friends invite me. We played for a while and then one of us couldn't do anything and it just sat there, so we reloaded and now only I could see the network games and had to invite everyone else. Also the method of resuming an online game is... an afterthought.Buggy, we ran into many crashes , cards would not cast at the end of your turn like they said even though they were qued, amoung many other incorrect spell castings.Dissapointing end game, just standing on the crown rolling 1 die every round with no option of leaving or backtracking, not sure who thought that up but it was bad. Players could just sit there and pelt you with spells build up there stats  and then kill you.Total dissapointment.The Music was uninspired.The price, $79.99 for the complete version, I won't ever play this again even if its free.

												Talisman the board game in digital version.Theres no point reviewing the talisman itself,its a dice board game.you toss the die,move and stuff happens.However reviewing the digital content of this board game.Pros:-You dont need friends to play and you dont need to play all the characters alone if you wanna play-AI seems allright-Easy to change rules-If you like talisman the board game you like thisCons-Bugs bugs and bugs. i played more than hour in 4 player game online,so far we were all at outer and one player casted spell. it crashed the game completely. there was noway going back anymore. that shouldnt happen,if that happens you simply dont release the game. there is no price on good game and that lost hour. after you get over that the game was lost you simply think,should i start new game what if it crashes again after hours of playing? these things should not happen in game like this,never. And this isnt first and last game breaking bug sometimes game forces you to do something because it jams every other option.-Sometimes gameplay is super slow,like when you cast spells it takes far too longIf they fix the bugs ill give this port 9/10 (9 cause it could look more pretty) and recommend it but until then 4/10 cause of the bugs in this game.

												Trying this on the free play weekend. 9 hours, 3 playthroughs against 3 AI opponents.The good:- addictive gameplay - would play with friends- content? (DLC, yeah...)The bad:- late game phases can get slow, even on max AI speed- BUGS. I had to kill the game on 2 different occassions, one of them being a crash to desktop. On another, a card effect (reduces movement to 1) got stuck on me despite the AI having and then discarding the actual card. Ended up quitting that game too. The game also loses fullscreen mode on each Alt-Tab.As is, I might still grab the main game on sale. No DLC though - I wouldn't want to support game devs who prioritise DLCs over fixing major bugs.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Ok, first of all there is no decent tutorial and the link to the rules leads you to an  extensive site full of text. First play I stayed completely lost in the game for several turns, the cards were showing up too fast and I had no idea of what was going on.After understanding a little of what was going on I tryed to play with random AI characters. I lost 3 encounters in a row on the first 3 tutns and died, while the AI got several followers and Items. Just a bad experience, ok I rage quit and restart.Second go: Oponent first turns rolls to other side of the river, flips 3 cards gets 7 gold. My first turn Dragon. Another bad experience, ok...Third try I realized I could set AI speed, I realized I could pause the game and check on the cards, but I still dont know where the buffs and debuffs are coming from, I loose battle even though I win battles, a guy fights me with 2 strenght and suddenly he has 8 strenght. I lost 3 turns in a row, frogged, one of my oponents has talisman, belt of strenght, solomons crown and a unicorn, I died once, got lost in cave and lost all my gold gambling.Long story short, I played the game times, never drew an equipment,the only follower i had was a hag and I died several times, while having no tooltips hints or decent tutorial, it took me an hour to realize my re-rolls were consuming fate counters and I couldn't understanding why it was not working anymore. I rage quit all of the games I started.Some my say it was just a bad luck or the game is hard, I see it as a very very bad experience that was worsen by the fact that the game leaves you in the dark.I still don't know what trophies are for, ehat happens when you fight a player, what's the point of capturing a wolf as follower and what or where is the chasm.[UPDATE]Just found out the dice rolls are rigged, no matter how many times I load the game on the same save spot, the dice results for ALL the rolls are the same, even the fate re-rolls are the sam. This was the most frustrating discovery so far. I don't know if there is a reason for that, or they just couldn't design an easy and simple dice roll algorithm.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												I have been playing this game for about 6 months now, and I've finally had it with this game. This game is FULL of bugs. The game will routinely change the rules on you and outright cheat to help the AI and screw over players. That isn't even the part that bothers me though. The game has had a problem with crashing and lost connections since I started playing, but it is now to a point where I can't go more than 2 minutes without getting kicked from a game. Even if I rejoin the game each time, the program will eventually crash and I am forced to close the game. This is not just my experience - all of my friends experience the same thing, and a quick search online shows that many people are fed up with these same problems. Do not even waste your time buying this game, the devs don't care about fixing the MASSIVE issues that make this game wholly unplayable. For how long this game has been on the market, there is no excuse for this. The devs should be ashamed and either FIX THE PROBLEMS or get this game off the market.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												For those who can't get to an actual table often (or at all) this is a great alternative to play Talisman.  Don't know what it is?  Think Fantasy Monopoly and you sort of have the idea, only instead of buying properties and gathering cash and boning your friends, you're fighting monsters, gathering treasure, gambling money, and... well, boning your friends.  It's an all-time classic board game.Only downside is they charge about the same amount for the DLC as they do for the real game's expansions, so if you actually can get a good regular gaming group together, getting the actual game is probably a much better course of action for you.Note: as of this writing, the DLC list has shrunk down to three, so the above comment may no longer be valid, but during the Early Access, you could see listed all the expansions for the physical game at the same price.  This may turn up later.EDIT: Don't know why my play counter is 0.  I've definitely played this a helluvalot more than that.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												7/10 - Lovers of fantasy board games, buy. Others pass...Pros- Lots of Characters- Lots of Cards, Spells, & Events- Easy to play while multi-tasking (TV, other games, ect.)- Online multiplayer content.Cons- Too much DLC- I swear dice are rigged vs AI- Graphics could be better.- Repetative music.- Many mechanics to learn & employ.So, I'm not big on board games. I got this in a Humble Bundle & decided to try it out. For a board game, it's pretty entertaining. That's why I gave it a 7/10 & a thumbs up. If it weren't a board game, I'd give it a 4/10. The game flow is pretty boring & the DLC is somewhat frustrating.It's great that they want to keep the game up-to-date, & I don't expect them to work for free. However there's a bit of a pay-to-win feel, when you're looking at some of the newer content. It's not just new event cards, or "Alternative Ending Cards". It's new characters with OP abilities, or OP "Runes" (upgrades to base stats).I also wish there was more flash & awe while playing the game. I mean, you pick up a "blizzard" card; you expect to see the board covered in a wash of hail! You have tons of spells, but nothing beyond the card's artwork to help you imagine the effect! The game falls a bit flat when it comes to graphic possibilites.The same goes for the music. It's not bad, but it rarely changes. It's so monotonous. With so many events & the dynamic of "who's winning", alignments, what board section your in, ect. you'd think there'd me more variety.I complained about the game's loaded dice vs AI. I rolled a "1" 5 times in a row on the same square. This happened twice in one game, then once again in the following game. While it's not impossible to do, it's highly improbable. If the dice aren't loaded, maybe I should play the lottery...There's some strategy, but for the most part the strategy is overriden by the RNG of the dice rolls. Personally, I'd be more entertained with a game of Magic the Gathering or Hearthstone. You have a greater feeling of control, knowing what's in your hand & in your deck. In Talisman: Digital Edition, nothing is guarenteed. You can have 8 godly items one moment; nothing the next. There's nothing you can do about it, & it just makes you feel like the game is a big waste of time.Lastly, there are a lot of quirks with regard to when & how you do things. I had a "Siphon Strength" card that I tried using for 10 turns. Suddenly it worked on an opponent that I never selected nor was he near me; just a random event. You need to learn which items are consumed on use, and which arn't. Or maybe you got turned into a toad. Is it worth it for you to land on that spot that gives you +1 Strength? Apparently not.If you like board games, then perhaps you'd be willing to learn all the quirks of this game. Personally, I'd rather play something more intuitve & gratifying. I may play this on occation if I'm stuck watching TV with the kids, but there are many other games that can fill the time with a better sense of achievement.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												One of the best board games of a long past era, Talisman evokes the core of 1980s RNG heavy dice rolling board games. For those of us who lived in that time, before Germany came along and showed the world how great board games can be, this is a well realized throwback nostalgia title. That's not to say Talisman is a great board game. It's really not. It's exceptionally RNG heavy and can be frustrating at times. But, it's also pretty fun. Particularly when playing with a group of friends over Skype, Mumble, etc. The game itself is very easy to learn. Roll a die. Move. Do what's on the board. Try to improve your character enough to get to the center, defeat the challenge, and win the game.The software implementation of Talisman by Nomad is pretty good. The animations and sounds are good, the graphics are pretty, and it plays the way you would expect. We've only run into a few bugs, one game-breaking, over a bunch of sessions. One of the really nice things Nomad did was allow the host's version of Talisman to be played. I have the full season pack, and a bunch of my friends have the core game only. I host, and we can play with all of the expansions.There are 3 expansions out so far. The best one at the moment is The Dungeon, which adds a large board segment to one of the corners. I'm very much looking forward to when all of the expansions are out and you can play a big mega game.Game time can run a bit long. While this is faster than the tabletop version, budget about one hour per player per game. I recommend, but this definitely isn't for everyone. I sunk about 100 hours into Talisman Prologue (which was their single-player "Beta" version of this and about a dozen hours so far for the full release. This is a fun one to pull out once in a while with friends, like any good board game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												About 2 years ago (mid-2013), Talisman Prologue introduced me to Talisman on Android, and i thoroughly enjoyed it. When Talisman came out, i did not hesitate to get it and have not stopped playing it since. i only got Steam Talisman working in a Windows VM today, so Steam still rates me as a Noobite, but i've got well over 200 Talisman sessions behind me on Android. It is a near-perfect rendition of the board game (which i have also bought since becoming a fan). Many consider it to be too random, but the fact is that it holds a lot of strategy (part of which is dealing with the randomness). Talisman is _easily_ my most-played Android game, and now that Steam works on my desktop machine (via a Windows VM), it will certainly become my most-played non-Android/non-Linux game as well.If any notable degree of randomness just makes you angry, don't try Talisman, but if you're looking for a lighthearted beer-and-pretzels style fantasy romp, Talisman might just fit the bill in epic form.Tip for new players: PLEASE, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, LEARN THE GAME IN SOLO MODE BEFORE PLAYING ONLINE!!!! Few things are more frustrating in online play than having to wait for new players to read every single card and every single square every single turn. So please, for the love of your fellow players, play it solo _AT LEAST 50 TIMES_ before playing online. Learn 90%+ of the cards and board spaces by heart. Your fellow players will appreciate it and will stop dropping out of games which you cause to drag on for 2 hours longer than necessary because you didn't do your homework before playing. Please. Thank you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												After putting +100 hours in this game, i decided to write my first review, to hopefully raise awareness to this amazing tabletop. Talisman is great for fantasy lovers and offers lots of diferent heros with different abilities to play as, which is one of my favourite features in a game. All the heros are fun, some more powerful than others, but every one of them can win if you manage to use its abilities to its full potential. Although there is some skill involved in this game, most of the player's performance is driven by luck. Preety much all actions (movement, combat, encounters) are defined/influenced by the dice rolls. This means that no matter how experienced you are, you can get destroyed by a noob who installed the game 10 minutes prier, which can be frustrating at times. Another thing worth noting is that there are lots of possibilities for turning the tide in the middle of the game. This means that even if you're losing completely and the other players have much better stats than you, theres always a chance one of them will suddenly turn into a toad (and therefore leaving all objects/followers available to pickup) and allowing you to get all his stuff. Or maybe someone is about to enter the Crown of Comand (the place you need to reach to win the game) and you cast a spell on them and force him to loose his Talisman, the one object that allows them to get there. This triggers a lot of people, but i personally think it adds a lot to the game, and even though this stuff has happened to me numerous times, i end up having a laugh about it because at the end of the day, the game is fun. Just note that there's never a guaranteed win/loss, and you can always hope for a comeback or fear your demise! Expansions make the game a whole lot better, and the more you have, the more varied the game becomes and the more ways there are to make your way up to the top!Pros: -Lots of fun with friends -Wide variety of heros -Playable on a toaster -Great to play at work (Tab in when it's your turn) -Unpredictable -Amazing when you have access to expansions -You dont have to purchase all the expansions in order to enjoy them provided that you play online with a player that owns them!Cons: -Very luck driven -Games are super long -Not as enjoyable if you dont have access to expansions -AI can be really dumb

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												This game is the perfect example of emergent gameplay done right. In one game, that forest might be the home of a friendly fairy that grants wishes to the forces of light, while in another, it might be the lair of a terrifying dragon. Using multiple decks of cards with different effects and uses, you can craft the story of an evil leprachaun, who loses all his money and ends up in jail after a night of drunken revelry, or the tale of a lone bounty hunter with an enchanted flail, on the trail of a powerful sorcereress who stole his magic shield and destroyed the academy that trained his superhuman fighting skills, finally clashing at the highest peaks of the world. In another of my games, my Bard character managed to ensnare a fire breathing dragon with his music. In another, my alchemist discovered a bag that always had an extra gold piece inside whenever you ran out of money, with his abilities, I managed to turn this unlimited supply of gold into unlimited magical power. If you immerse yourself into the experience and roleplay it, stories build themselves right in front of your eyes. Every game is different, and with every expansion adding new locations, decks, characters and everything else, It can only get better.The AI isn't too bad either, I've seen characters doing crazy stuff like casting the offensive wind blast spell on themselves to fling across the map so that they're closer to where they need to be.If I could change one thing, it'd be the introduction of a way to turn off the victory conditions of the game, sometimes you want these random storied worlds of yours to live on longer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												7/10 - Lovers of fantasy board games, buy. Others pass...Pros- Lots of Characters- Lots of Cards, Spells, & Events- Easy to play while multi-tasking (TV, other games, ect.)- Online multiplayer content.Cons- Too much DLC- I swear dice are rigged vs AI- Graphics could be better.- Repetative music.- Many mechanics to learn & employ.So, I'm not big on board games. I got this in a Humble Bundle & decided to try it out. For a board game, it's pretty entertaining. That's why I gave it a 7/10 & a thumbs up. If it weren't a board game, I'd give it a 4/10. The game flow is pretty boring & the DLC is somewhat frustrating.It's great that they want to keep the game up-to-date, & I don't expect them to work for free. However there's a bit of a pay-to-win feel, when you're looking at some of the newer content. It's not just new event cards, or "Alternative Ending Cards". It's new characters with OP abilities, or OP "Runes" (upgrades to base stats).I also wish there was more flash & awe while playing the game. I mean, you pick up a "blizzard" card; you expect to see the board covered in a wash of hail! You have tons of spells, but nothing beyond the card's artwork to help you imagine the effect! The game falls a bit flat when it comes to graphic possibilites.The same goes for the music. It's not bad, but it rarely changes. It's so monotonous. With so many events & the dynamic of "who's winning", alignments, what board section your in, ect. you'd think there'd me more variety.I complained about the game's loaded dice vs AI. I rolled a "1" 5 times in a row on the same square. This happened twice in one game, then once again in the following game. While it's not impossible to do, it's highly improbable. If the dice aren't loaded, maybe I should play the lottery...There's some strategy, but for the most part the strategy is overriden by the RNG of the dice rolls. Personally, I'd be more entertained with a game of Magic the Gathering or Hearthstone. You have a greater feeling of control, knowing what's in your hand & in your deck. In Talisman: Digital Edition, nothing is guarenteed. You can have 8 godly items one moment; nothing the next. There's nothing you can do about it, & it just makes you feel like the game is a big waste of time.Lastly, there are a lot of quirks with regard to when & how you do things. I had a "Siphon Strength" card that I tried using for 10 turns. Suddenly it worked on an opponent that I never selected nor was he near me; just a random event. You need to learn which items are consumed on use, and which arn't. Or maybe you got turned into a toad. Is it worth it for you to land on that spot that gives you +1 Strength? Apparently not.If you like board games, then perhaps you'd be willing to learn all the quirks of this game. Personally, I'd rather play something more intuitve & gratifying. I may play this on occation if I'm stuck watching TV with the kids, but there are many other games that can fill the time with a better sense of achievement.

The hompage is broken since days and not providing a link to Bloodmoon, not a single link to the new rules and the bugs, people seems to be happy, but Nomad isnt able to deliver a bug free game.Ifi wouldnt love the table top game, i would remove this game from my account. Pro*Digital version of the classic GW board game.*You can now play with up to 6 players in one game.* Cross plattform gaming.*Added 3 free copies to give away for every Gold buyer*If you play online with friends/familiy you can/will get your fun (if your game will not disconnected or crash).*Nice artwork*If you are a Talisman fan, then this is your way to buy it and i suggest you just ignore the contra points. Contra*Slow development (3-5 months for a new DLC is a long time, i paid the full season price more then 2 years ago and i only can say that the development is slowing down with every new DLC, there is no ETA when the final game will be released)*Massiv bugs, dont get me wrong bugs get fixed (from time to time), but this often ends in new bugs, before i released my last review i was a long time beta tester (and naming the issues of support and constant fails with updates was the reason why .i was removed from Nomoad) that helped for free to lure the bugs. Well iam sure that i have to point out that  9/10 of all my latest games shows bugs (some game breaking some minors ones).*MP (public games) is most of the time a place for leavers and quitters.*The ai is improved compared with the one years ago, but still not worth to buy this game for a single player. You only can cheat the game (you add runestones to the ai and give them a big advantage)*They changed there Season Pass conduct, and released one DLC (The Shaman) without giving it for free to the former buyers.* A constant dropping number of people playing online on Steam Finally i have to note that ca 400 of my hours where used for beta gaming,  and as a long time supported and as a former member of most of the groups and even the founder of the german group. number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I made the mistake of playing this, being a board game aficionado of sorts. I like to think I "play" a "decent amount" of "board games".I chose poorly here. Talisman is as follows: Roll dice. Go to space. Draw card. See what happens.That's it. There is no planning, no strategy, no thought. Roll dice. Highest wins. I rolled more dice in 2 hours last night than I remember rolling at a lot of longer sessions of Dungeons and Dragons, and yet no a single one of the dice I rolled during the game of Talisman really meant anything. The content is repetitive and the game is a chore to play, as several points are designed to arbtrarily lengthen the game simply based on a die roll, teleporting you back to previous portions of the map, or lowering your stats (forcing you to grind more adventure card sto 'level up' again), or simply kill you outright (the vampire rolls a 6. Lose 6 life. You died. Back to start.)And then, oh god, once you get to the end, you have a 50% chance of doing one damage per turn. I have never so fervently hoped for the dice to roll high so that I could die and the game could end, but the sweet, soothing release of death did not come. At the end, I watched a Wizard AI waltz up and slay the Fighter AI player who had gotten there mile sbefore him, nad had be simply rolled a 4, a 5, or a 6 at any point during the 9 turns he was on the Crown of Command, would have won the game. But he did not, and so Wizards win over martial classes once again. Thanks Wizards.In its defense: This seems to be a well done translation of the board game. The automation works well and outside a few quibbles like trying to figure out how to queue spells, the game worked well and both players realized how to do everything (aside from trade in trophieS: I looked at  aSteam guide for that) within a few rounds. But unfortunately, in this case, it's not really a plus: We figured it out so quickly, because there's just not that much to DO. So as a technical translation of a boardgame, it's very good. I am sure avid fans of Tlaisman will garner a greta amount of fun from the game, though I'm not sure I'd want to be there with them.You might as well roll a 1d6 before the game starts, and highest winner places themselves on the cente rof the board and wins, because that's about what Talisman boils down to. "More content" unfortunately would not fix what is an un-fun game to the core. At least Risk mitigates its dice rolling with the ability to actually choose and think over whta you do before you fling plastic cubes about.

												There are alot of things done good in this game: They didn't change the rules or the cards, the graphics is good, the AI's play reasonably good. number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game. Whilst I have many fond memories of Talisman from my childhood, this is a terrible implementation of a game that has long past exceeded its best-by date.Talisman itself is sadly lacking in the current era of boardgames, with little to no strategy or choice left to the player. It is dictated far more by the random roll of the die, than any particular desire of the player. Even Monopoly provides more strategy, and choice of action. This is a faithful implementation of the original, for what little that is worth.The main issue is the interface, which is an abomination. Trying to play with friends rapidly becomes an excercise in extreme frustration, wherein you battle the shoddy controls - instead of battling your friends. Laggy, unresponsive and unintuitive are the nicest words I have to say about it. I wish I could refund it, and I feel terrible for gifting it to several of my friends who now all have a much poorer opinion of me.If you have any fondness for Talisman, any decent memories of the game - leave them as that, memories. Playing this game will leave only a bitter taste in your mouth of ashes and defeat. Nomad Games has my money - please dont give them yours.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												You'll have already read what the game is: a faithful recreation of a board-game classic with high fidelity to the original, a somewhat sketchy interface, a few bugs, and the same glacial pacing as if you were playing around a table, minus the board setup.AI is one of the keys to transition between in-person and computer-based play. The programmers haven't solved that problem well at all. Computer opponents don't have much strategy besides accumulating stats and items. They perform like mediocre bots in the single-player training missions of an online FPS. A human player would wipe the table with them every time, except the AI appears to get a boost via favorable die rolls and card draws, likely to disguise its lack of real strategy. The first few games this doesn't matter much, but after dozens of games it sucks the enjoyment out of it.If you have 3 friends willing to play the game with you, I'd buy this game in a heartbeat. If you're going to fill in with computer players--and especially if you just want to play single-player--this is probably a pass. For that reason--plus constant problems connecting with servers resulting in interrupted games--I have to give this game a no vote even though I generally like it. It's not a horrible purchase, just know what you're getting into.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Івенти, дайси, рок-н-ролл!Майже кожен з нас у дитинстві бавився в настольні ігри: монополія, "сходи" тощо. Кидай собі кубик, совай фішки і гати бізнес/опонентів. Тема більш серйозних настолок в пост радянському просторі розкрита слабо. По-перше, це дуже специфічна забава: деякі настольні ігри (особливо за редакцією правил D&D) настільки складні, що для розуміння найбанальніших аспектів потрібно витратити чимало часу на ознайомлення з правилами. По-друге, коло фанів та гравців хоч і розширюється, проте недостатньо швидко: знайти компанію для гри в реалі доволі тяжко. Проте розробники Talisman - комп'ютерного аналогу одноіменної фентезійної настольної гри від Games Workshop взяли курс на широкі маси.Та незручна мить, коли параметр "Удача" прокачаний на 1Суть гри на перший погляд виглядає доволі тривіально: ось тобі карта, ось тобі персонаж. Мета: "всіх гепну і буду царювати". Тут варто зробити уточнення, що сценаріїв є достобіса, але всі вони доступні лише в додатковому контенті... Проте відривати кревно зароблені гроші не обов'язково: стандартна карта доволі реіграбельна - велика кількість унікальних персонажів, що доступні зі старту, дозволить розбавити ігровий процес. Рухаємось ми по карті кидаючи ігрові кості ("дайси"). Якщо результат нам не дуже підходить, використавши один бал долі можна перекинути дайс. Також ця особливість стосується і певних локацій на карті (відьма, чаклун, цвинтар тощо). Особливо недитячий накал пристрастей і бурління емоцій викликають моменти, коли, в надії перекинути на що-небудь, окрім того що було, гравець отримує те саме значення на дайсі. 99% ragequit'ів і пригорілих штанів припадають на ситуації, коли вдруге випадає єдина нейприйнятна подія з шести можливих.Пересунувшись на певне поле, ми тягнемо карту з колоди подій. Події можуть бути різними: від дракона до того самого Талісману, який дозволить нам пройти до фінального рівня карти і, подолавши усі перешкоди, почати робити масовий абзац менш везучим опонентам.В процесі екстермінатусу ворогів нам допомогатимуть шмотки, супутники і навіть нейтрали (заваливши певну кількість істот можна прокачати магічну або фізичну силу персонажу). Проте, хоча багато чого і залежить від удачі і випадковості, не варто сліпо на неї покладатись, адже карти з закляттями і купа різного спорядження існує не просто так. Мудрі рішення - запорука перемоги. Для тих, хто любить очима Графомани можуть йти лісом, дивитись тут немає на що. Все гарно промальовано, але не більше. 2D інтерфейс доволі зрозумілий: якщо на карті стоять хрести, то це кладовище, якщо стоїть храм... Ну, ви зрозуміли.Ложка дьогтю в банці медуПохила навчання доволі крута. Перші 2-3 гри ви будете вигрібати механіку і задавати питання "Що я? Хто я? Чому я?!". Другий біль - відсутність локалізації: якщо ваша англійська складається лише із "My name is Vova" - бути біді. Тексту багато, читати його треба, інакше вашому протеже настане каюк.  Інший мінус - наявність у онлайн іграх тролів або людей, які через тільки Богу відомі причини стають AFK: чекання по півтори хвилини на хід гравця (яких може бути до 4х) вибішує жвавіше, аніж виступи наших депутатів. Трохи покращує ситуацію автозаміна хронічних слоупоків ботами і можливість продовжити гру пізніше.- Зараз буде шістка!- Ага, кидай вже.- Нуууууууууу....! [censored]!!!!!!Гарний тайтл, якщо є компанія друзів (зі знанням англійської) з якими можна забацати конфу в скайпі і розібратись, хто найвезучіший покидьок на селі. Трошки осторонь стоїть гра з незнайомими гравцями по Інтернету. Отже якщо ви запросто зриваєте джекпоти в казино або хочете долучитись до серйозних "настолок" і ваш інгліш включає не тільки сакральне "F*ck you!" - ласкаво просимо

												DnD the board game. Really fun board game that is entirely based on dice rolls, no skill involved what-so-ever. Cannot recommend this game without the dlc, the additions to the board and extra characters are a must have, the base game will not keep you entertained for more than a few hours but with all the trimmings its endless fun. I cannot recommend this game sadly because it crashes very frequently and has no saving or drop-in/drop-out feature for multiplayer which means you can play for HOURS AND HOURS and then all progress is lost. Amazing game, IF it worked.

Posted: April 5, 2015
												I own the boardgame in its original form for at least 20 years now and I absolutely love it.When this software version of the game was announced I was really intrigued about how well it would turn out.Here is my advice vor players of the original boardgame:AVOID AND DONT BUY THIS F*CKING BAD CONVERSION OF A ONCE GREAT GAME AS YOU WOULD ALSO NATURALLY AVOID THE GAMES WORKSHOP VERSION OF THE GAME !!!And here is why:- Not all characters are included, you will have to buy them seperately like in the games workshop version- Fullscreen doesn't work properly on all setups. You will have to minimize the steam window else the game will always turn to windowed mode at startup- the boardgames original graphics on the board itself are way (and I mean WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAYYYYYYY) more detailed than the blurry♥♥♥♥♥♥they serve you in this conversion here (though I have to admit I don't own the games the Games Workshop version of the boardgame, so it may be they are poorly done and do suck nowadays too.)- Some rules can be changed (what is good) but why can't i for eg say let's have "N" numbers of randomly chosen characters to select from in the beginning?- The descriptions on the single fields on the board don't include the inscriptions (and they wouldn't have been able to be read either if impelemented in the same blurry way like the background graphics), you have to click on them first to see it, and it must be your turn to be able to do so. WHY THE HECK? Include a tooltip you d*mb*ss programmers ... how old are you?- ...You know what? I don't have the time and / or the mood to write more about this as it turns out to be more and more to be a list of easyliy implementable ideas others get paid for. So if you wanna know how to do this game "pixelperfect" to it's true original form than contact me if you are one of the devs.One more thing:You wanna know the moment I rage quited the game?Here it is all about it:I played an elv. I found a wizards staff and got myself a spell. I wanted to use the spell the next round because I disliked the one I got and wanted to get a new one (by using the staff again). The spell was the one that blocks another player or enemy for one turn. As I should select one character to cast the spell on I selected a figure of another player on the board. This didn't work. Then I thought, ok click on the charakters Icon and I clicked on myself to test if it works and you know what? It did work. It showed my card AND another button where I could choose to do cast the spell. BUT NO "GO BACK" BUTTON?WTF?!?!?!?As I said, contact me if you want to overdo this game to a GOOD game that is worth the big name it's released under, but don't expect to get more infos or ideas for free ... Or is it free to get all the characters THAT FOR ALL TIME WHERE INCLUDED IN THE ORIGINAL VERSION OF THE BOARDGAME in this software version?...And now everyone please hate me for this review and vote me down ...*lol*@ngel

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												There is a lot to be said about the charm of nostelgia... but not enough to deflect the idea that time can be cruel and that some things, like Talisman, do not age well.This game is quite a nice digital version of a boardgame from long ago, but as such it does not have the benefits granted from all the game development that would come after it.That is not meant to be a cruel jab, if anything is is an apology for why I can't find much positive to say.All you really need to know is that this game is an excercise in being given a very small set (usually 2) of options each turn based on the roll of a die. those options are then resolved throught the roll of another die... and then that loop is repeated for about an hour or more with plenty of long pauses taken at random intervals.Your input into this game is so small, and the luck so great that it is hard to truely feel that this game needs you to be present, or that any sucess or failure is yours to claim.The translation from cardboard to digital is well done and smooth in most places, but does have a few flaws, (there is no option to hide all of the A.I.'s desicion making if you are playing with bots, and it can only be sped up so much in the options... meaning that your already drawn out experiance is now stretched further and thinner.)It can be applauded for being such a faithful replication of a board game, but as to wether that excersice is, itself, worthwhile, my feelings lead towards: No.If you are an old board gamer who maybe missed out on this little bit of gaming history and wanted to experiance it, this is a good way to do so, but if you are anyone else, there are better digital board games, much better non-digital board games, and infinitely better digital adventure simulators.Try any of them before this.

												I would love to give this game a recommendation to purchase as it should be a fantastic game.  However, if you are thinking of buying this game, do not waste your money until the game bugs are all fixed.  The fun in this game should be the online gameplay. I've started well over ten games now and have not been able to finish one - every game has crashed! The game always crashes, and this really should have been sorted out before releasing the game.  Quite frankly, steam should refund all purchases as the game is completely unplayable and unfit for purpose (if it were any other product it would be breaching trading laws).  How the company can contine to sell expansion packs is beyond me - the original game needs massive improvement first.  You will waste your money if you purchase this as it will lead to no end of frustration in the online mode and  will be no enjoyment at all.

												A little bit too complex for its own good.   A game took me a good two hours with myself and three AI's, and you couldn't speed the AI turns up enough for my liking.  The second game was broken by an elf who spent the entire game teleporting between two forests, increasing their stats endlessley.  I would like to try the board game though.I played two more games to completion with 2 AI's, and the game is just way too random.  The frog mechanic can move a character from first to last place instantly, and sometimes there's nothing you can do to prevent it.  Getting the rolls you need to win is incredibly difficult, and once someone gets to the Crown of Power they almost always win.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												This game is full of bugs. The worst one even doesn't let you start the multiplayer match in 4 out of 5 tries, when the option "Character selection" (out of 3 Chars) is enabled, which usually is enabed for fair play. When this happens, the first player doesn't get a hero to choose from and so the room needs to be rehosted. More than that, the game crashes randomly or you just disconnect from the server, with sometimes beeing unable to rejoin the game. I've made a 4 player match where one player left the game at the beginning. Not a big deal, it happens often and the KI took over and the remaining three players continued to play for three hours. Then the player who left returned, which caused a crash to the other three players, while one was already at the crown and the game would have ended 10 minutes later. Great, three hours played for noting than frustration. The commentary of the returning player: "Oh, I made it back right in time". D o u c h e b a g -.-Singleplayer works fine, KI is ok, but since you normally want to play against other humans and not against the KI, this game sucks more often than it makes fun.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												Unless you're a huge fan of the original board game you might want to give this a pass.On the surface it's fine. There's a board. There are cards, characters and a die. Great. Unfortunately once you actually start to play you realize pretty quickly that you're dealing with a tablet port that's had oodles of time put into it on the dlc-front, but not so much on  the optimizing-for-pc front. There's the base game, then several expansions, then I don't even know how many characters for a buck or three apiece, and there ain't a thing wrong with any of that assuming the game plays well and stable on the average pc.That's where things begin to break down. There's a very long-standing and unresolved bug affecting a lot of people wherein if you afk from the game for anything more than about 60 seconds or so you'll return to a frozen screen, which you can only "fix" by force-closing the game in Task Manager and restarting. There's thread after thread after report after report on the Discussions page, and each says the same thing: "File a bug report and email it to us w/a log" and that's about it. There's been no solution to date, one year on, but boy oh boy have there been dlc galore in that time.The game interface itself is, to be charitable, minimal. There's very little in the way of options in the settings menu, in the main game UI you'll be left to pretty much figure things out on your own since there's no tutorial of any kind, and no game manual that I've ever been able to find that outlines basic rules, etc. I played the game for months before realizing that I could click on the bar at the top of the screen that shows the current turn, and that that would show me details about turn events like card text, who rolled what, and so on.In the same vein there are very, very few input options. You may use your mouse, and... that's almost it. Again, I played for months before discovering that clicking the spacebar = selecting whatever option is at the top right on your screen, be it "encounter space" or "move here" or whatever. There are no keys that do anything else whatsoever that I've seen. Again this is something that's been requested for a year on the forums, the ability to map some keys to common actions, and from what I can see the response has been the same every time: "Because it would take a lot of time to code for different OS's, the game is kept basically in a tablet state to make it simpler on us devs". Again, that constraint hasn't stopped them pumping out character and expansion dlc. That's the gist of it, anyway, so ask yourself if you want to pay 15 bucks for a tablet game on your pc.Game bugs: no shortage of 'em. Spell queueing is hit and miss, at best. Sometimes they work as you expect, other times they don't fire off at all or they do but not where you intended. There are cards that don't work at all in certain situations and cards that work in unexpected ways in others. Multiplayer games freeze and/or disconnect a random person, in addition to the aforementioned single player freeze. There is little to no hovertext, which in a game where you're forced to play with your mouse almost exclusively leads to a LOT of clicking. If you want to remind yourself what stipulations exist on a certain game square, for instance, you must click that square. This is fine unless you accidentally double-click, which is easy enough to do, at which point your character *moves* to that square whether you're finished reading its text or not. The same goes for many cards like spells or potions. Be careful clicking on them if you're simply trying to read them. One extra click and poof! there goes that spell you totally didn't intend to cast yet.I could go on but there's not much point. It *is* a game, and it *is* playable, but it isn't all that enjoyable to me to the point I'd recommend it to anyone, and the reason I go so far as to give it a thumbs down is simple: after months of waiting, pleading, begging the devs to show a little love to the pc community (whose money they seem to love enough, alright) their response was to post a new thread announcing an upcoming new Talisman game they're working on. Presumably we were all meant to shout "Yay! Take my money!", but to me it felt like someone who'd just mugged me asking if I'd like to buy my wallet back.Again, if you're a hardcore fan of the original, this will probably fulfill your digital desire to play, but it ain't gonna be a bug-free or hassle-free experience. If you're new to the gamel I'd recommend giving it a pass, unless the devs decide to pay it the attention they should've been paying from the start.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Talisman is the classic adventure board game of powerful magic and ferocious creatures. Play as one of many classic fantasy archetypes such as an elf, wizard, monk, thief (and many more!) as you gain experience, powerful items/weapons, followers, spells and so on. Adventure around the board until you're ready to tackle the dreaded inner region, reach the Crown of Command, and claim victory! If you like gameplay that is all about playing the odds, you'll probably enjoy yourself in Talisman. At first glance it seems like a simple roll-and-move game where the player has little control over what happens to them during any given turn, but it's actually very involved as winning requires understanding how to create good odds for yourself. It's also a game where you need to understand that bad things WILL happen and there's nothing you could've done about it; or even if you lost a fight you shoulda won - it's ok because 80% odds in your favor means you'll still lose 20% of the time. Talisman is a very interesting mix of a laid back casual game (because of how simple any given turn is) and also a very cutthroat game. Players will clash in many PvP battles over the course of a game and powerful items will switch hands as players take them from each other through force or other means. You'll need to always take into account the other players, knowing which ones you should target and which ones will target you.So if you like fantasy adventure and gameplay that's all about navigating the wims of random luck, I highly recommend Talisman. It's a light game that manages to capture that feeling of going on an epic quest and overcoming great challenges. There's a reason this game is still around despite many bigger and more involved adventure board games being released since the 80s, so play this digital adaptation and find out what makes Talisman so special.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
Do not buy unless it is on sale for $1.Talisman is one of the best board games that have ever come out. However, I am talking about the original board game, not the digital edition. I am not going to describe the single player feature as it is very poor and AI does not demand any thinking from the player, making the single player game easy, boring and discouraging. Therefore, I will concetrate on the multiplayer feature since it is the only feature worth looking at.The rules are very simple: roll a dice, move that many spaces, draw a card or cards, read them and d what the instruction tells you to do. Simple isn't it? Well, for developers it is not simple. The game is full of bugs and developers insist on working on new addons instead of correcting existing bugs. In other words - the game is not finished and really rushed and I need to point out it was released a long time ago. Too long for such issues to happen. The game can freeze or crash just after loading it. I experienced game freeze on the main menu several times - solution, do not leave the game on the title screen or it will stop responding. You will be forced to start the game again and/or start Steam again, and/or reboot your system.The game was not properly tested before release and it is more than obvious.  A lot of cards do not work as they are supposed to. Many card effects lead to a dead end as you will not be able to do anything (I see that problem with many spells while casted on other players). Example: after casting for example, Misfortune spell on the opponent, the game stopped responding and did not give any player any opportunity to make their moves, the game stops, the timeout counter freezes and you or any other player is forced to leave the game in order to make it move on. Connection issues occur every game. Some players are kicked out of the server for no reason. Sometimes you cannot go back to the game you were playing.  After joining the server and starting or looking for a game, your game can stop responding, forcing you to reboot your game and ocassionally your Steam and/or your system. Who put Quit button in the Settings? Standing ovation for the analysts/architects/developers and anyone responsible for this sensible chuckle design. I laughed, my friends laughed. Good comedy. There is no way to speed up the game play. It goes very long and I played some games for such a long time that I do not recall any actual board games to last that long (and I played with 7 people at a time!). You have to wait for every action even if no action is available at the moment. For example: even though you have only one choice, the system does not automatically go with the only choice but waits for you to select it. Bad idea. There is a number cards that do not work properly or do not work at all and when it comes tot he interaction betwen some cards, majority of such situations lead to a glitch, mostly forcing you to rejoin the game or restarting it. Each new addon comes with a new set of bugs. Beware. Random Number Generator is really poor and developers should think before they do something rigged as this. There is a chance that you will throw "1" for about 5-10 times in a row which is impossible if you were really rolling dice. This NEEDS to be fixed. I remember rolling the same set of numbers several times in a row. Bad development. There is no explanation for such bad execution of dice roll simulation. You can be kicked out of the game without any chance (yes!) for coming back. The game tends to bug out and nothing can be done to go back to it. Progress is lost. The most disappointing. Inviting your Steam friends is very buggy. I have never successfully invited anyone without a crash, so I do not use that feature.TL;DR - If you want to play the great game which is Talisman - go and buy the original board game, you will never have to reboot anything, wait for anything to happen, look at bugs, being surprised that nothing what the card described happened. Digital edition is faw away from being a good product. It is fair for now, but it is closer and closer to being bad if noone takes care of basics like card working. Less development on new addons, more at bug fixing, please.I paid $1 for the game and that's how much it is worth Pros:- Classic Talisman game!- Many addons and characters that make games more interesting- You do not need addons to actually play them, only one person in the game needs them- Very good music- The cards are taken straight from the board game version!Cons:- The game is not finished- Bugs ruin the game experience- Connection issues that seem to go worse with time- No way to join the game that is currently in progress - in the board version that's what makes this game so attractive, no matter how many people are currently playing, you can always join- Bad mutliplayer and overall game issues force players to leave the game early (ruining the game)- Less and less players (20 average) playing the game online (which is very sad)Do not get me wrong = the game is fun but the way it was developed forces you to abandon the idea of playing. Board games are not supposed to be that frustrating when it comes to gameplay. This game would be better if not rushed so much. If developers concetrated on the Basis of the game instead of looking for easy cash selling characters or addons - I would recommend it 100%. Sadly, I cannot do that and reasons for it are mentioned above.These issues are serious as I see less and less players online.
