content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												There's no satisfaction in winning or losing as the entire game (except for the spells aspect) is based 100% on luck. I'd never thought I'd find a game based more on luck than Monopoly, but here it is. If you like to strategize then this game is not for you, your ability to reach the end and win is purely determined by dice rolls and luck of draw cards (all dice rolls are pre-calculated before the game starts). No strategy will overcome events like being turned into a toad 7 times within 8 turns (yes this did happen) or losing a fight with a 60/50 chance of winning 13 times in a row (yes this happened too). Talisman is really just a dice simulator with music and ren fair style graphics, and just ended up in my uninstall pile.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Talisman is a very poor board game to begin with. Main game mechanic is frustrating the player. A dice game that goes on for 3-8 hours. The Digital edition is a bad port of the board game. It forces you to watch hundreds of die-roll animations every game. It's bug-ridden and you can not expect anything to work at any time - it will just not function, at random critical moments. Interaction with the game is often non-intuitive and cluncky. You can forget multiplayer as it crashes at random roughly 9 of 10 games. Talisman Digital Edition runs a DLC greed-scheme, where they offer you the game piecemeal for an insane price. This is as bad as it gets.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												2 Words: DLC marketplace. Its one thing when you have dlc in your game, its another when the minute I try to create a game I'm slammed in the face for not having 90% of the content available. This is most evident in the player selection where it shows you the 6 heroes you own and the 50+ that you do not in a hodgepodge of little icons with no labels.Look, I can understand having DLC as a part of the game, but DLC constitutes almost 4 times what the base game has to offer. And if you really want to enjoy this game, its basically mandatory. Avoid this marketing strategy and avoid this company. A 14.99 game should not feel like an incomplete experience and have dlc content that is pushed this heavily on its players. Expansions are fair, but DLC should not be required to enjoy the game nor be pushed as heavy handedly.

												Not recommended for single player.Played the demo through several games. Did not play multi-player only played single player.Ran into game breaking problems with the AI in single player:1.) AI is dumb as a rock. It was way overpowered from running around the board collecting loot/kill trophies but instead of attacking it continues to run around like a headless chicken. I sit at the crown square and roll one dice (d6, 1-3 no damage, 4-6 1 damage to all enemy) over and over and over and over....bleh Can't move out and I'm using a melee character so only option was rolling every round. I was actually hoping the AI would crush me to put me out of my missery but quit game and started another. 2.) There was a healer card on the board at the forest during one game. All other AI's dead from attrition by d6 crowning them. The elf can teleport from woods to woods so there I am rolling d6 at the crown square and the elf just keeps warping from woods to woods back and forth healing. That's it. It's a stalemate, unbreakable loop. I can't move, attack, nothing while the elf just teleports from the woods with healer to another woodland square than back again. Well played AI, you have defeated me with boredom.Shut the game off and decided not to purchase after playing demo.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												My first gameplay...Picked the Gambler.Rolled low, went to Tavern. Got drunk, lost a turn.My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Dragon with 7 strength that rolled a 6. Lost a life.My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Craft 5 creature that rolled high. Lost a life.My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Pig with 1 strength.OMG.. I'm going to beat it. Pig rolled a 5. Beat me by one point. Lost a life.Lost the game.Beat by bacon. 10/10 Would lose to bacon again.---------------------UPDATE: The game can be fun.. but after finding out that all dice are predetermined at the beginning of the game I will not be recommending this and giving it a thumbs DOWN now. This is a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor mechanic and development choice for any developer. Why give people the illusion they are rolling a dice for random rolls if they are not truly random when thrown? Those times I'm feeling lucky and end up with those craptastic one's make me feel cheated since I now know they were picked when I started the game. Coding in a SIMPLE RNG routine for each roll is NOT that hard and actually would use less resources than storing up a predetermined roll chart. I know this because I AM a developer. You wanted to prevent people from reloading a game and possibly rolling a better RANDOM roll? **WRONG** The same principle can be used by that same person because they know what the next roll is going to be and they just reload and choose a different course or action. You haven't foiled their attempt to get ahead.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												This is not a computer game. It's a board game on a computer, which is perfectly legitimate.But how does it stack up as a board game? Even there its basic design fails.Don't get me wrong. There are some great things about this board game, especially the replayability and variety of interesting scenarios (for a board game), if you're willing to fork over money for a lot of DLC. However, where the game fundamentally fails in two areas:1) You have very little ability to control where your character goes and what it does, which means you can spend long portions of the game just wondering around, rolling dice and seeing what happens (or doesn't happen, as the case may be). This makes the game very luck based, but worse than that, it becomes pretty tedious, especially when the board becomes filled with cards that effectively don't do anything.2) It's really hard to end the game; partially because the game requires you luck out on a series of dice rolls just to get to the point where the game starts to end; partially because the game doesn't really penalize you at all for trying to power up indefinitely before heading to the end game; and partially because the first character to get to the end of the game gets the dubious honor of being forced to sit there doing nothing but rolling one die to see if maybe they'll do 1 point of damage to the other characters.With some of the above problems fixed, Talisman could become a fun board game/computer game, but as it is, you spend most of your time waiting for your turn in the hope that you'll get to do something interesting.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I'm a lifelong board game fan, and bought Talisman: Digital Edition to see if I would like it well enough to purchase a tabletop copy for my collection.  Unfortunately, this digital edition has bugs and glitches that have kept me from finishing a game, primarily with AI getting stuck - unable to make a decision, and unable to force the AI to continue.  What I learned is that Talisman relies almost entirely on luck - rolling dice and drawing cards for everything.  Not enough strategy for my tastes.  And this digital edition still seems to have serious issues that make me not want to play, despite decent art and music.  If you like the fantasy theme, stick to the tabletop version, or try Descent: Journeys in the Dark instead.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												This game is well-made, well-designed, but not worth it - even if it's on sale.Along with most board games of this design (such as D&D) the designers only feigned giving their players the ability to develop sound strategies and some sense of control, when in reality, it's a crap shoot - so in that respect - if you don't like actual strategy games this isn't for you.If you like games that crap on you when you're doing well - this is pretty good - the designers did keep the element of "Life Happens" that goes along with board games of this type, allowing this much instability without crashing the game is pretty amazing though.In summary, this is NOT a strategy game (as it was listed) - it is a pretty good rogue-like rpg, just not one I'd recommend

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Plays really slow. Compared to Talisman: Prologue, I would say just buy whichever is on sale. Both have slow interfaces and annoying control methods. The actual board game is legendarily slow to play and these two games take the physical slowness out of the equation, but insert slowness and clunky controls where you feel like virtuality would lend itself to smoothness.Sometimes you need to click the board to do a thing and the game will interpret your click as something else, and you'll mess up your turn. Sometimes the game's controls will screw you. All I can recommend is to be as careful as you can.If you're a big fan of Talisman but you don't have friends who want to play the game on Steam with you, just buy the real board game. And if your friends want to play the Steam version with you, know that it will be annoying.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I love the board game.  However, the board game is, frankly, a bit flawed.  Talisman, in a nutshell, is: roll a die, 1,2,3 bad, 4,5,6 good.  Repeat. and repeat... and repeat... and... well, keep going for two hours.  If you like Talisman, then get this bit of nostagia (yes, there are new versions of Talisman out, but really, the first edition was the best fun).  I don't like all the add on packs for such a primitive game.  I also do not recomend multi player for this game (it deserves to be played on a table).  Not for anyone who does not have experience with the board game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Not recommended for single player.Played the demo through several games. Did not play multi-player only played single player.Ran into game breaking problems with the AI in single player:1.) AI is dumb as a rock. All it had to do was move foward to the command square and crush me. It was way overpowered from running around the board collecting loot/kill trophies but instead of attacking it continues to run around like a headless chicken. I sit at the crown square and roll one dice (d6, 1-3 no damage, 4-6 1 damage to all enemy) over and over and over and over....bleh Can't move out and I'm using a melee character so only option was rolling every round. I was actually hoping the AI would crush me to put me out of my missery but quit game and started another. 2.) There was a healer card on the board at the forest during one game. All other AI's dead from attrition by d6 crowning them. The elf can teleport from woods to woods so there I am rolling d6 at the crown square and the elf just keeps warping from woods to woods back and forth healing. That's it. It's a stalemate, unbreakable loop. I can't move, attack, nothing while the elf just teleports from the woods with healer to another woodland square than back again. Well played AI, you have defeated me with boredom.Shut the game off and decided not to purchase after playing demo.

												Love it. I first played this board game when it came out in the 80's and loved it. I have played it several times since with various expansions and seeing it come to life digitally brought back so many memories.It is practically identical to the original board game, and does have a few annoying bugs (mostly around spells not quite activating the way they should) but outside of that this is a really well done port of the original.It is just as unbalanced as the original board game but the runestones go a small way to helping that out, bringing the weaker characters into the mix nicely.Recommended and looking forward to all the future expansions. Bring on the dungeon!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Talisman: Digital edition is a game I had never heard of before this free weekend.  I immediately liked the game.  This Talisman: DE is a digital Board game, literally.  You play as a variety of classes trying to buff your stats and make it to the center of the board before anyone else gets there.  The game relies heavily on RNG type randomness, Most actions involve dice rolls, and most "encounters" rely on the way the deck is "shuffled".  Another thing to note, I don't know if I'm just unlucky, but this game is long, I have been in the same game for about 4 hours now. no one has come very close to winning yet. I don't know how long the average game against the ai lasts, but mine are always terribly long.   Overall though I like the gameplay and art a lot. The art reminds me of classic Dungeons and Dragons art, and less grimdark games workshop art. I recommend this to anyone still interested after all that. I dont know  what kind of player will like it most really. If you get it, I hope you have fun!

												Still far too buggy. AI players can get trapped in descision trees, that loops the game until You quit. And again playing the AI - every turn takes too long - The AI is scripted as a hot-seat player. No need to show all the control options. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												The interface is an absolute MESS. It's too easy to cancel a card effect when you think you're just selecting a different target. You can't read the board during other players' turns. You CAN look at their inventory, but when you right-click on someone's card to see its details it doesn't zoom in on that card, but rather opens up a sort of "card carousel" that you have to shuffle through to find the card that YOU ALREADY CLICKED ON. Keeping track of everything feels like an unfun version of Papers Please.I get that Talisman is an old board game that is unapologetically "Ameritrash", but the fact that the game is so clunky made it that much more important to streamline the digital version.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												This does the board  game version a lot of justice.The cards and squares are accurate, the art is the same and the gameplay is fluid.There have been some issues with crashes which I expect to be resolved soon and during the AI or other people turns you are unable to look at other squares of the board to become more familiar, but these issues are very little.The AI does tend to make some silly choices that most people would try avoid but I imagine this will be patched soonOverall 4/5+Accurate when compared to the board game+Fast and Fluent gameplay+Soundtrack+Saves your game-A Few bugs-No Tutorial for new players

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												I don't understand how the metascore was so low... then again, i don't use the metascore as a solid guide anyways.  I would recommend this game to folks who are in to fantasty board games. i thought the game was fairly simple and it only took me about two games to fully understand the concept and what the characters do.  i have had a grand time with friends who also purchased this game.  i would not necessarily recommend the game to individuals who want to play by themselves.  some of the matches can last up to 3 or 4 hours and playing by yourself is just not my cup of placenta.  talisman is fair in the sense that it is chance; your battles are similar to that of risk, however you build on your attributes such as strength and craft (magic).  some characters have neat perks to assist you in acquiring the talisman to reach the center of the board.  the characters provide you with a bit of variety and the adventure cards and item cards you get to draw are numerous.  i find the game both amusing and entertaining.  i would recommend this game if you like old school board games i.e. dungeon (from gary gygax in 1980.) hope you cats have fun too! <3

After that we clocked in 12 hours before the end of the day after we bought it. Yup.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Spend your time with RNG.Also, crash a lot in multiplayer.A lot.Granted it IS a fairly done rendition of the board game, but lack of added features combined with difficulty of certain things in-game that are easy to do in real life (like just taking a closer look at a particular area) make this less than a stellar pick.  As a recreation of the board game, not the worst.  But as a computer game overall, not good.I don't regret the money I spent on this, but I *really* cannot recommend this unless you're a fan of the board game. If you are a fan of the board game, pick it up; you can typically find a game at least on Europe server (and you can easily see different servers for different areas of the world and switch between them), though you will crash, you *can* rejoin so it's not the end of the world.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												A beautiful, well-designed, well-engineered video game adaptation of an absolutely godawful board game.Talisman is one of those games that people keep playing not on its own merits (it's about as strategic as Crazy Eights and takes HOURS for a game) but because of the nostalgia filter.If you have fond memories of this game from your childhood or early gaming days, then this is an excellent way to play online with added computer opponents. If you don't, then I recommend grabbing a deck of cards and playing War. At least it's over faster.

												How anyone could let a merry band of amateurs spoil such a wonderful board game?! 												A board game based on a real thing, obviously, however it seems that board games are more enjoyable when you are sitting around it with friends to share in the experience with. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												Not a very fun game unless you enjoy praying to RNGesus. I played my first and last game against the AI to learn how the game works. Got to the crown around turn 60, then spent another 60 turns sitting on that space doing nothing. Once you get to the center you're stuck rolling until you get booted or you kill everyone. Meanwhile, the AI jerked around in the outer ring of tiles healing up at least as must damage I was dealing from the crown.While sitting through this mind-numbing experience I found that you can set "house rules" to end the game when someone reaches the crown, or to stop healing when someone is at the crown, but the fact that there are such glaring design flaws in the base game is pretty unforgivable.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I love board games, and I like a lot of digital versions of board games. This is NOT a good one. If you loooove Talisman and know the rules and cards very well, you may like it. If not...the game is very slow (even at highest speed), clunky, and boring. I only played a couple hours and it literally consisted of clicking dice roll, and then moving that many spaces. This is just not a game that works well without friends present.Additionally  the layout of the game is just plain confusing. There were so many times I was trying to click on cards to read them, then accidentally moved there, or did something else. The interface is not intuitive at all.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Buy the board game, and walk away quickly from this digital debauchery.Each of the cards at least seems to work exactly like the board game, though the interface leaves a ton to be desired. Game may crash after finishing a round, stays in windowed mode at all times, ignores most key presses, no help dialogue, and on and on.The game likes to automate SOME the things that are player choices (like using the Orb of Knowledge) and other times make you click Continue way too many times. The worst part about it is  the inconsistency. There are actually times where your turn is finished for you, even if the timer doesn't run out. Another issue there: there's a mandatory timer! Shortest timer is 30 seconds, longest is 2 min.Overall, this version taught me some things that were a little confusing in the tabletop version, but via teeth-pulling. If you're a hardcore fan, buyer beware.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Awesome game. Truly one of the best board to digital game i've ever had the opportunity to play. The add-ons are completely worth it as well.  Now for the bad news. There have been multiple instances when playing with my group of friends where someone or multiple people will drop connection. SOMETIMES, you can resume game (which is a cool feature) but othertimes it just will not work. It gets really funky. Now, to me, there is nothing worse than spending 2.5 hours on a game with 3 other people and right as it's getting good the multiplayer takes a dump all over and we can't finish the game. The support is also non-existant (thanks Nomad) so don't believe this will change any time soon, but if enough people are buying and playing maybe that will change (I highly doubt it. Wishful thinking maybe). TL;DR: Solo play is worth it at sale price, but mulitplayer is a big risk although it is insanely fun.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Brilliant digitial port of this classical adventure boardgame!  If you liked playing the original boardgame you cannot go wrong buying this.  With the added bonus of no taxing setup and no errant pets/children suddenly destroying the game position as well as the ability to simply exit from your game and then resume it at a later date (works with both single and online gameplay) with no hassle.  Excellent online community allows lots of replayability once you've mastered the AIs efforts.  With the game getting constant further expansions and updates this game can only get better.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												As the Germans would say, "Na Ja". Games like this shows the flaws in the Steam review system. I'm going to have to give it a recommendation, simply because it did entertain me for a couple of hours, but however much fun with the family a board game like allows at Christmas, playing on a screen is just boring. For the uninitiated let me explain.For the first couple of hours I was enthralled. Learning all the rules, all the magical cards and their powers, all the items and followers. I thought I found something really deep to get my teeth stuck into. YAY! 4 hours in, I come to the damning and sad realisation. I am playing monopoly, in a D&D setting... but it's still monopoly. Aka, roll a dice over and over until you win or lose. The lack of strategy and the high percentage of luck mean that the hour long games that are needed to complete Talisman feel like little more than flipping a coin over and over to see who gets more tails than the other. So 5/10 from me... but if you see this for a buck and want a few hours novelty, it could be worth it!

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												A  fun and entertaining game, however the AI is complete and utter, bull. I can not stress this idea enough. I spent half an hour trying to kill the only remaining Swashbuckler in a 1 vs. 5 AI game. He would not simply die. What i mean by this, is that he would honestly get down to 1 life point remaining and then miraculously roll the die into the perfect number to land on a square in which he could heal. It did not also help that he had a card that gave him a minimum of 1 gold at all times. The game finally ended when the AI moved him into the most inner ring where he had no methods of self healing.  Overall it's a great game and lives up to the experiences i've had through the actual irl gameboard. However this game requires a lot of patience. I don't reccommend this game if you don't like waiting forever to end the game. (If the turns are slow, you can fix that in the advaced settings.)

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Talisman: Digital edition is a game I had never heard of before this free weekend.  I immediately liked the game.  This Talisman: DE is a digital Board game, literally.  You play as a variety of classes trying to buff your stats and make it to the center of the board before anyone else gets there.  The game relies heavily on RNG type randomness, Most actions involve dice rolls, and most "encounters" rely on the way the deck is "shuffled".  Another thing to note, I don't know if I'm just unlucky, but this game is long, I have been in the same game for about 4 hours now. no one has come very close to winning yet. I don't know how long the average game against the ai lasts, but mine are always terribly long.   Overall though I like the gameplay and art a lot. The art reminds me of classic Dungeons and Dragons art, and less grimdark games workshop art. I recommend this to anyone still interested after all that. I dont know  what kind of player will like it most really. If you get it, I hope you have fun!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I love a great boardgame but let's face it, these "cardboard children" - to borrow a line from RPS - can take a LOT of table real estate to play. Talisman is a massive game in its "analog form" and with all of the expansions and four players, the setup is considerable and games can be marathons. But that's all good as boardgamers expect that. That said, Talisman Digital Edition fots nicely on my PC, requires mere minutes at most of setup an most importantly, captures the sheer fun of Talisman, Isn't that why we play games, for fun?A few negative reviews commented on the woeful AI. But, perhaps these folk are playing the prelude titled Talisman: Prologue. I have found the AI to be pretty good. And let's not forget that Talisman is largely a luck based game. All of the so-called tactics I have seen and heard about the game must still bow to the capriciousness of the deity known as RNG; even an AI like Deep Blue cannot predict the vagaries of dice rolls.There are a few issues that linger. One of the most annoying is when an AI opponent draws an event card. Unless you are a speed reader or you know every Talisman card by rote - and with all of the expansions in the physical boardgame there is an insane number of cards, you won't have time to read what the event is. You have to zoom in on the board section where the event is. The same holds true for other non-spell cards. This has been brought up to the devs but as yet there has been no fix for this.The digital version allows you to earn runes which grant advatages in gameplay. [AI also collects these as well]. I like the mechanic as it lends a sort of leveling up feeling.The Dungeon Expansion is next up and I cannot wait for its release! If it is as faithful as the physical version of the game, it's going to be a blast.I think that Talisman Digital Edition is a wonderful introduction to the fun world of tabletop boardgaming and it scratches the itch of tabletop boardgamers who want to play without the crazy setup and rather forced solo variants for the physical game found round the interwebz.This is a STEAL at the price and I would advise buyers to spend a little extra dosh and get The Reaper and Frostmarch expansions as they add considerably to the game.I hope that more boardgames experience a digital conversion. Are you listening Games Workshop and Fantasy Flight?EDIT: 18 November. The Dungeon expansion really ramps this game up considerably. The AI can be quite nasty and that's good as Talisman is a cut throat game. I am hopeful that the devs will release Blood Moon and The Dragon next. These two expansions literally change the game, adding a bit more unpredictability to a game that can punch you in the face already and have you smiling about it.UPDATE January 15: Ya gota love this developer. With the latest update there are two new free characters. These two are not even present in the physical boardgame but were last seen in the 1986(!) version of Talisman. More achievements plus what seems to be a hint that the Highland expansion is next! This is very cool as it is a one of the big corner expansions!!

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												I have waited for a digital version of Talisman for a loooong time! I am really happy it finally happened, despite developement trouble. Pretty much everything is like the original board game. Pro's: Beautiful cards etcFantastic musicChoose how fast the AI thinks and camera speedHouse rules avaliableFINALLY I CAN PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT FUMBLING WITH CARDS! :DCon'sThe interface is not very intuitive, before you learn how the system "thinks" you'll probably accidentally cast a spell on yourself or something stupid like that.. I sure did ;)There are unfortunately a few bugs, I walked into a game breaking situation because of it. You can get stuck in loops where the AI just walks around in circles, there's no way to break the loop since you are entirely helpless when the AI is taking its turn.It's a bit slow sometimes.All an all tho, its super fun!!And the expansions are worth the money, AT LEAST the ones where you actually get a new region and not just cards.

												Steam really needs a thumb sideways for games like this.On one hand the game seems to be a faithful adaptation to the board game (from what people say. Ive never played it) The game is realativly fun and it has an online option.The other hand though.... I encountered a slew of bugs/glitches which ended in some actions not being counted or moves being skipped. The AI is horrible. They refuse to go into the inner section until they are around 13 in their stat and they make a lot of stupid moves. A mectric ton of dlc that kind of feels like its to much when the base game has very little to offer in terms of chracters/boards/and cards.If you like the board game and want to play it then im sure you'll have a decent time with it. For everyone else though, I would avoid buying this unless its very cheap or on a humble bundle.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												As a little boy I was always curious about the Talisman boardgame. Now it came to Steam and on a sale I took my chances. Pros: + Great art & figures just like the boardgame.+ Long game time (depends how you look at it)+ Various characters to choose from, each with their own special skill(s)+ Some interessing items, followers & spells to get or sites to visitCons:- To much depends on the lucky dice rolls- Because of the dice rolls, the game can drag on and on, even if you have the Staff of Command- Long game time (depends how you look at it)- Imbalances on character front. A thief has 100% chance to Steal from you, even if you are the most powerful character on the board. It would be more interessing and more fair that the victim is able to save and hurt the thief when caught. Same for a sorceress with Beguile.- Did I already say it depends to much on the lucky dice rolls?Personally, I enjoyed it first but later on the myriad of (un)lucky dice rolls, character imbalances & to long game times diminished my enjoyment rapidly. I would rather spend my time on other games where I have much more controle at the games progress - and I have to blame my own stupidity - than on the sheer luck of a dice roll.If they do some tweaking to give your chosen character a fairer chance/saving roll against some odds, I might take another look at it and change my mind about it . . .

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Although I never played the board game, I can easily attest to the fact that this game brings the worst out in yourself and your friends, which in itself leads to hilarious and memorable moments. That, coupled with the random nature of the game, is in my opinion its greatest strength, as it allows everybody to compete on an even level. The randomness might get frustrating in single player though and I clearly recommend that you band together and buy the four pack, so you have somebody to play with, because the social aspect of the game is half the experience.On the downside, the technical aspect of multiplayer matches does have some hiccups. I have experienced sync issues and game crashes a couple of times, which is aggravating when you are about to wrap up a game session, which easily runs in at about two hours. This shouldn’t keep you from buying the game if you have some friends around to play it with though.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Almost identcal to playing the board game with a few major exceptions. the most important being speed. A real life Talisman game can usually take up 6hrs. With the turn speed for the PC ramped up to 10 I finished my first game in 3hrs.  This is not a problem as playing well in games causes you to level up unlocking new stuff. Quite what I'm not yet sure as it will take more than one game to level up. The other major difference is price. A full set of Talisman with the expnasion will srt you back nearly £100 for the physical version.I do love my physichal set and this does lack the atmosphere of having some like minded mates round for a good boardgames session. But as an introduction to the game or as a way of killing the hours over the summer while your mates are on holiday this is highly recomended. Also if you have friends who play but dont live locally it is also possible to set up an online game over the web.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												After taking 2 hours to learn the game with a couple playthroughs, we set up for a final game of the night. Rolling Thief, a few drinks in, I decide to fully immerse myself for this playthrough and give it an honest try. The adventure began, and McStickyfingers was unleashed upon the world. Turn one, McStickyfingers immediately heads to town and run into the Black Market. What a perfect way to get a head start, he thought, and jumps at the opportunity to pay 1 gold for a full suit of plate mail. Being the most obnoxious and unsubtle Thief in the land, McSticky is caught and hauled off to Jail to reflect on his life choices. Seven turns in, the world around him is passing by, with another filthy bandit behind bars. A wanted poster for anti-thievery is picked up by a travelling Pirate, passing through town. Ironically, the Pirate ceases his own mischief and pledges to ensure McSticky remains off the streets. "There is only room for one bandit, here!" - He thought. McStickyfingers is finally released from Jail on the eighth turn. Has he changed? Did he learn his lesson? You may ask him. In turn he would respond to you with a question, "Are you kidding?" Upon release, McStickyfingers immediately runs into the Pirate and steals the wanted poster of himself right out of Pirate's hands. The world is surely doomed, now.Many turns go by, which means many items are stolen from anyone and anything. A collection of swords is made within' McStickyfingers' inventory - one from every player leaving each of them unarmed. It isn't long before Death himself is unanimously tasked to put a stop to the McStickyfinger shenanigans. Fumbling around with his shiny swords, McSticky is caught from behind and beheaded with one stroke of the scythe. Was this the end? No. More like ...are you kidding? At the end of Mr. Grim's action, McStickyfingers is revived and immediately re-gathers his belongings before anyone else can act. It seems not even Death can stop the reign of McStickyfingers' mischief. It isn't long before deals are made from the other adventurers to our beloved Thief to spare their inventory from his sticky fingers. Gold is thrown in his direction from every which way.Having never given up on his quest, wanted poster or not, the Pirate is behind the scenes with an anti-theft bag to stash his belongings. Arming to the teeth, a rivalry is born. To be continued...10/10 would go on epic thieving heists again.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I played the Talisman board game with my old gaming group and we would have hours of fun taking us into the wee hours of the morning without even realizing it. This game brings all that fun back, but with the option to save and quit when the sun starts peeking through the windows and you need to hide away for a few hours.However, it does feel like there are still some bugs to work out, such as abilities that can be activated 'at will' don't seem to be available to use when the 'at will' need arises. This may be a bug or I am missing the prompts to give me that opportunity. The only other downside I can see is you are not physically sitting at the table with your friends as you play to toss around the smack talk and make deals on the fly to take a problematic character down.All in all, this is a fantastically fun game to play and all of the expansions are more than worth it for the added content and additional characters. You would be amazed to see a Courtesan beating the heck out of a Dread Knight when things go in your favor.Definitely worth your time and money and everything goes on sale with some frequency. The standalone characters are also worth it if you grab them on sale. Otherwise you'll have plenty of others to play with un til they do.

Posted: February 12, 2016
												Don't take any notice of the meta score, they don't know what they are talking about.Just the base game can be a bit vanilla, the fun of the game increases a lot with the expansions.If you are a fan of table top games then you will probably like this. A digital recreation of the proper board game.There are a few things that are a bit buggy, and they are being sorted. I've not come across anything game-stopping.A game with 6 players and expansions can last 9 hours +. Or you can set a limit on a number of turns.You can save games, and start another.I've not tried live multiplayer, only against the AI, which is very good, but sometimes leaves you wondering why it chose a certain action over another. Maybe I just don't know the strategy well enough yet.This is one game that I will be coming back to again and again.Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Talisman is a reat PC tabletop board game. similar to Dungeons&Dragons or Pathfinder in the role playing sence. You choose a character and roll dice to move him around the board collecting items and fighting monsters, until you have high enough stats and you've aquired the "Talisman" to get you to the "Crown of Command" to win the game. Very fun and entertaining if you have friends to play with you. HIGHLY RECOMEND You get the DLC expansions though!!!!!!! The normal game is kinda lame, but if you have the city, highlands, dungeon, and a few character packs... it sooo much more fun! (best part is, if u have say 3 friends, only 1 needs to buy the expansions.. then he/she hosts the game, and for that game, you have it too! Hope you all have fun :)

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Do you have friends to play table top games with, but you don't have place to game/you live far away from each other? Fear no more! Thanks to digitalizing board games, you can play Talisman online! Want to play with family/friends in home but you hate all of the cards everywhere/you're just to lazy to even think about cleaning it up later? Just start that little beast up and have fun! But putting the fun review away, the game is great, it's the same as the board game, instead on computers screen.Only one thing i have to mention that i DON't like, when you play with friends coach style not online, it's really hard to fast swap the mouse from one another to cast spell mid someones move/turn, the time limit for that is just ridiculous (or I am just blind and I don't know how to change it, then please, tell me how)And the AI, it's dumb as hell, don't even play with AI (even for the first time, just get a friend or sister or someone from the street and play!)I highly recommend it!

Posted: February 12, 2016
												Don't take any notice of the meta score, they don't know what they are talking about.Just the base game can be a bit vanilla, the fun of the game increases a lot with the expansions.If you are a fan of table top games then you will probably like this. A digital recreation of the proper board game.There are a few things that are a bit buggy, and they are being sorted. I've not come across anything game-stopping.A game with 6 players and expansions can last 9 hours +. Or you can set a limit on a number of turns.You can save games, and start another.I've not tried live multiplayer, only against the AI, which is very good, but sometimes leaves you wondering why it chose a certain action over another. Maybe I just don't know the strategy well enough yet.This is one game that I will be coming back to again and again.Highly recommended.

												Before you fully consider my recommendation, consider the following:-This game is riddled with bugs, everything from annoying to flat out game breaking.-I've had A.I. wait for their timeout before doing their move.-Worse yet, I've had A.I. that STILL won't move after their timeout. ESPECIALLY if you have a friend or two you can play together with while simultanneously skyping.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												A fantasy boardgame turned digital. Very fun with friends, but the UI/engine is a little buggy. Online multiplayer can cause disconnects sometimes, but luckily there's a fast and easy "retry" function which automatically remakes the game and starts at the last turn played.Players pick from a pool of characters and take turns traveling around a spiraled board with three regions (four if you have the expansion) where each space on the board has it's own description of an action that affects play. The characters each have their own stats and abilities which makes re-playability very high. It feels a little unbalanced as some characters feel better than others since they can snowball given their unique abilities, where others don't seem to take off until deep into the game. As time in the game progresses players collect monsters as trophies, collect cards, gold, or battle each other to collect stat points. The objective is to get enough stat points to go past the required spaces on the board and get to the center space to claim victory.It's a game of dicerolls, but having more stats or inventory cards will improve your odds by a huge margin. There are weapons that increase your strength or craft, armor that will let you re-roll to save yourself from taking damage, items that give you magic spells, etc... but it still comes down to the luck of the dice. It's very frustrating when you're getting beat down, but very satisfying when you're doing the beating.In short, the game is good fun with friends, but I can't imagine playing it by myself.

content:

												I used to play the old boardgame in the early 90s, fond memories. I wondered if the digital edition would even be true to the original. I tried it and was not disappointed! We can save our game if interrupted for dinner or if it gets too late and continue at another time, which is a bonus compared to the board game.I recommend it to any fans of the board game, you will feel right at home. If this is your first contact with Talisman, you have to see past the average graphics and lack of fancy animations and use your imagination to immerse yourself in the game. If you can do that, you will enjoy hours of solo, hotseat or online fun!

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												For fans who grew up playing the 1st thru 4th table-top editions of Talisman by GamesWorkshop, this was an absolute gift from Nomad Games. Those new to the Talisman phenomena are in for a real treat! This Digital Edition blend of traditional board game, card-based game meets RPG, truly is fun and easy for all ages--if you like fantasy turn-based games. Content keeps coming via DLC of existing Fantasy Flight Games' table-top expansions plus some new characters unique to Nomad Games. Do yourself a favor: Buy Talisman DE Gold, get all future upgrades included, and get all kinds of enjoyment from this gem.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Firstly ignore the metacritic score, I haven't read the reviews and I'm not sure why it's so low, my only thought is there were a lot of bugs when the game first came out which probably impacted the score; but a lot has been improved upon since then.Excellent game. Like boardgames? Then you'll like this. Like the original Talisman boardgame? Then you'll like this. I've played the boardgame several times, and quite enjoy this as it takes out all the hassle of setting the game up. Granted playing the boardgame is still lots of fun.There are the odd bugs but the developers are still active, killing the bugs and adding new things to the game (I haven't played in a while and was greeted with a updated UI during the game which I felt improved it!) Also newly added to the game the ability to play with 6 players, AI, local or online.There's hours of fun to have with th ebase game without the DLC, the DLC adds more depth and variation to the game but isn't needed; unless it's been changed if an online game is played only the host needs to have purchased the DLC meaning if you're lucky you'll get a preview of DLC too.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Pay no mind to the Metacritic score, those critics reviewed the game when it first came out.  At that time it had a huge number of bugs and other problems, particularly with multiplayer, but those have been entirely rectified.  This is a fantastic adaptation of a great board game.  It takes a long time to play, especially with a lot of players; less time than the actual board game though since you don't have to bother with setting it up or putting it away.  The game itself is quite a lot of fun for any RPG and board game lover.  It's a great value too, especially if you pick it up on sale (and it goes on sale fairly frequently).  The only real downside is that the AI is still terrible, so you're pretty much limited to playing with friends for a worthwhile experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Great Game, so long as your playing with other people.My only three gripes about it would be the AI opponents, Runes, and the online connectivity.The AI is not the greatest. They do some incredibly stupid things, things not even new players would conceivably do. And often with certain characters (Ogre, Necromancer, Ghoul, Minstril to name a few) will not even use the characters abilities at any point in the match. Runes ruin the experience if you use them, and make certain characters blatantly overpowered compared to others. Most people do not use them anyway, so it's not that big an issue, but i just don't see any benefit for them existing.And for online, connections can be a bit shakey at certain times of day, but so far the dev's have been working hard at relieving that issue, and its shown (for me anyway).There are a few other bugs here and there, but they are also being dealth with all the time, and usually don't interfere with a match.A friend of mine has said Hot-Seat Multiplayer also works quite well, so playing with real friends just like you would on the physical version is a plus. If you like board or tabletop games, or decent games to play with friends, pick up Talisman: Digital Edition. The season pass is also worthwhile considering all of the content that is ahead. Overall its one of the better games i've played in the past year or two.

												I purchased the game through the Humble Bundle and so far I have been impressed. Online does have some issues. 1 play through online took about 3 hours and we had 3 total disconnects. Anyone who is a fan of board games and have a few friends willing to play with then this game is worth the purchase and with these factors I would give the game a 7/10 in its current form. With more NET improvements and Spell casting changes to make it more intuative I could say my rating going higher.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												The Pros:The game is pretty. The art is pretty much as I remember the board game. The UI while unintuitive does cover most things. Winning can be fun.The Cons:Losing can be really boring. Being stuck on the command crown for endless turns whilst your one remaining opponent wanders the outer regions merely healing when you get the command spell to hit (every 1 in 5 times, and I started that end game approach with 8 fate) is not my idea of going out in a blaze of glory. The AI makes no attempt to get near you once you are down to two players.There are many moments of frustration in the game. Many of them aren't particularly meaningful except as an "I gotchya" tweak that the game pulls on you. (Being unable to control when some spells go off, having situations where you are forced to target yourself with abilities or spells because the UI doesn't allow you to back up, losing all your items/gold/followers to bad encounters, rarely ever burning a fate point that actually helps, the list is probably endless.) That said if you are a fan of random, I think this game really hits that spot. Whilst Catan (the online version) is kind of sad for not having multi player options, Talisman does have this.I can't say I think much of the pay to play nickle & dime approach (and what big dimes they are!) but it is nice that you can customize what you get in terms of characters/boards. I haven't done that but I expect those who want to enjoy multi player will eventually get the relevent characters. One thing seems a bit inobvious but is probably true anyway: You are able to win with any of the characters. The key being that you spend the time to learn how that character survives and adapts appropriately. Some might have a steep curve.I am recommending this game with a 6/10. Meaning: "caveat emptor" if you have problems with random games. It is fun once you set aside the disappointments and frustrations.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Having grown up on Talisman 2nd Edition, I have grown to appreciate and enjoy 4th Edition. It fixes a lot of issues that were present in 2nd. Starting characters with high craft are no longer at such a steep disadvantage to those of high strength. The inclusion of the fate mechanic can help ever so much with catastrophic dice rolls and, for myself, makes being evil desirable.Digital edition is based off 4th Edition rules and faithfully done so. This game is, as of writing this, still a work in progress, so there are bugs to work out. However, the development team is continuously releasing patches to fix problems and content updates, to include new expansions and characters for those who have bought them.For those who enjoy Talisman, I recommend getting the season pass, which unlocks all content for T:DE in perpetuity. As a fan, it's nice to be able to play without the bothersome setup and clean up (or other players, often).

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												A real fun game for you and three buds!!!  You have characters to choose from and they all have special abilities that effect game play. The base game has plenty to choose from so don't worry. Each player begins at a character specific start square on the outer ring on the board. The board is made of three rings of space each with location names on them, some of these locations also have special abilities that effect your pawn. You have 2 sums that are used in combat, strength and craft, then life, fate and gold all of which can be leveled up or chipped away at to reduce them lower that starting amounts.You roll a random generated die and move to the tile options you come up with, than you draw an adventure card that may be a monster, loot, item or event to challenge youor the other players. The object is to level up collecting items boosting your stats and fighting the other players, It plays just like a board game- one player after another takeing turns but as the game goes on the difficulty and struggle increases. You want to get to the center of the board crossing through two "rings" of board tiles to get to the tower where you take control and cast a spell that slowly kills off the other players to win. After a game is finnished you claim XP and level up to the next level where you can get bonuses to the pawn you pick for the next game.WARNING!! The games seem to take a long time to play through, I've played many- finnished two and both of those took longer than 3 hours to play. Lots of fun! Very replayable, lots of laughs with your friends.If you like tabletop games, GAMES WORKSHOP games you should enjoy this one, I got it for 5 bucks on sale but can say it is worth the full price. The game also has lots of DLC in the form of new player characters- ($1.99) each and several boards or expansions... ($5.99)) and up.-Mr. GrAnD

												Отличная настольная игра, чем-то напомнила мне Джуманджи с детства, картонные карты, фишки, кубики)))) Как и в большинстве настольных игр, чем выше значение сумм кубиков, тем лучше. Ходишь по карте и тебе попадаются всякие ништяки, которые помогут победить и преуспеть. Еще есть уникальная штука, как смерть с косой, которая ходит по пятам, когда она меня догнала, у меня была паника: "Что же это? Все? Гаплык?", но тут, волшебные кубики, и выпало 7 и черт возьми, смерть меня отпустила))) В общем, если хотите вспомнить старые настольные игры, обязательно скачайте, а еще лучше, с друзьями поиграйте(=

												I can't judge the game against the old board game as I have never played it.  That being said, the game has a great variety characters, gear and encounters to make your e-board game experience feel like and adventure.On the down side, the game can seem to drag on due to alot of unlucky rolls.  It can get so bad, that die rolls don't feel so random.  If this was Yahtzee, I could get bonus yahtzees with 1 rolls all day long on the Crown of Command.  I am guessing they have nerfed some of the game mechanics so players might be more inclined to buy dlc instead of grinding it out.  Perhaps I am being cynical, but I enjoyed the base game at a discounted price, so I will give it a thumbs up.  If I had paid 79.99 for the complete game, I would definately not recommend it.   There is no groundbreaking, earth-shattering, gameplay (in the base game, nor the dlc) that justifies that price.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												A real fun game for you and three buds!!!  You have characters to choose from and they all have special abilities that effect game play. The base game has plenty to choose from so don't worry. Each player begins at a character specific start square on the outer ring on the board. The board is made of three rings of space each with location names on them, some of these locations also have special abilities that effect your pawn. You have 2 sums that are used in combat, strength and craft, then life, fate and gold all of which can be leveled up or chipped away at to reduce them lower that starting amounts.You roll a random generated die and move to the tile options you come up with, than you draw an adventure card that may be a monster, loot, item or event to challenge youor the other players. The object is to level up collecting items boosting your stats and fighting the other players, It plays just like a board game- one player after another takeing turns but as the game goes on the difficulty and struggle increases. You want to get to the center of the board crossing through two "rings" of board tiles to get to the tower where you take control and cast a spell that slowly kills off the other players to win. After a game is finnished you claim XP and level up to the next level where you can get bonuses to the pawn you pick for the next game.WARNING!! The games seem to take a long time to play through, I've played many- finnished two and both of those took longer than 3 hours to play. Lots of fun! Very replayable, lots of laughs with your friends.If you like tabletop games, GAMES WORKSHOP games you should enjoy this one, I got it for 5 bucks on sale but can say it is worth the full price. The game also has lots of DLC in the form of new player characters- ($1.99) each and several boards or expansions... ($5.99)) and up.-Mr. GrAnD

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This game is probably a bit coloured by nostalgia for me, as it was a fond summer event to meet my cousin that had this game and we had a lot of fun with it, even without any expansions. This game is a very faitfull adaptation, and the expansions have never been more accessible. They are doing hot-seat right with regard to hidden cards. And a great set of houserules avaliable. If you are not familiar with talisman, it is a very laid-back game where the focus is more on experiencing stuff than actually making any big decissions that matter. This newer version include a faith point system that older versions didn't have, that somewhat alievates the otherwise a bit "snakes and ladders" feel the game might get when you are used to it. So recomended if you want a easy somewhat competitative game with fantasy theme (the theme is strong with this one). If you want more challenging decissionmaking there are probably better options.

												Talisman is a really fun game that I usually play with a few friends from time to time. We would often try to send the Grim Reaper after each other and see what happenes. There's usually one person in the group who goes into the dungeon area (can't remember the exact name). It has a mixed feelings of D&D, HearthStone, and a board game (best way I can think of to describe it and my feelings about it).I haven't  played this for very long, so I can't give a very good review of the game, but personally, I do find it really interesting to say the least. The game confuses me at time, but wtih people you know, you'll be able to figure the game out in no time. On a side note, it's an enormous amount of fun with a group of friends (or people you know). It's not as fun playing this alone, having done this on a number of occasions. The game isn't for everyone as it may be a bit slow pased. Personally, it's a good time passer when I have some free time on my hands.But what I can say is that, if ever playing with me, please note that playing the game any time past midnight, Terrible decision will be made on my part.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												After taking 2 hours to learn the game with a couple playthroughs, we set up for a final game of the night. Rolling Thief, a few drinks in, I decide to fully immerse myself for this playthrough and give it an honest try. The adventure began, and McStickyfingers was unleashed upon the world. Turn one, McStickyfingers immediately heads to town and run into the Black Market. What a perfect way to get a head start, he thought, and jumps at the opportunity to pay 1 gold for a full suit of plate mail. Being the most obnoxious and unsubtle Thief in the land, McSticky is caught and hauled off to Jail to reflect on his life choices. Seven turns in, the world around him is passing by, with another filthy bandit behind bars. A wanted poster for anti-thievery is picked up by a travelling Pirate, passing through town. Ironically, the Pirate ceases his own mischief and pledges to ensure McSticky remains off the streets. "There is only room for one bandit, here!" - He thought. McStickyfingers is finally released from Jail on the eighth turn. Has he changed? Did he learn his lesson? You may ask him. In turn he would respond to you with a question, "Are you kidding?" Upon release, McStickyfingers immediately runs into the Pirate and steals the wanted poster of himself right out of Pirate's hands. The world is surely doomed, now.Many turns go by, which means many items are stolen from anyone and anything. A collection of swords is made within' McStickyfingers' inventory - one from every player leaving each of them unarmed. It isn't long before Death himself is unanimously tasked to put a stop to the McStickyfinger shenanigans. Fumbling around with his shiny swords, McSticky is caught from behind and beheaded with one stroke of the scythe. Was this the end? No. More like ...are you kidding? At the end of Mr. Grim's action, McStickyfingers is revived and immediately re-gathers his belongings before anyone else can act. It seems not even Death can stop the reign of McStickyfingers' mischief. It isn't long before deals are made from the other adventurers to our beloved Thief to spare their inventory from his sticky fingers. Gold is thrown in his direction from every which way.Having never given up on his quest, wanted poster or not, the Pirate is behind the scenes with an anti-theft bag to stash his belongings. Arming to the teeth, a rivalry is born. To be continued...10/10 would go on epic thieving heists again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Okay, right off the bat, this is an awesome game to play! So much fun to level up your character, gaining strength and craft to fight enemies with. The object of the game is to reach "the crown of command" in the center of the board. However this is not so simple. You will have to go on different quests throughout the game to gain an object known as a "Talisman" to get the various places on the board. You will need one as you travel from the middle region of the board to the center region. However many things could happen between getting one and getting through to the center region. A player could fight you and kill you. A witch, bear or demon could spawn on you and destroy powerful or useful items you're carrying. The worst? Being turned into a toad. This is where all your items are dropped in the space you have turned into the toad. While playing as a toad, other players can pick up your items. It's a very challenging game and extremely time consuming. The 8 hours i have played.. 6 of them is just one full game of talisman, where unfortunately i did not win! I have the actual board game too and the digital version helped me learn it better as it gives you tutorials on your playthrough. Of course these can be turned off! If you are a fan of fantasy, board games and strategy then this one is definately for you! For what it is, i give it an 8/10. The game itself is excellent, but as i say you need a LOT of time spare if you're wanting to finish a game!

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												If you like board games then this game is great.  You'll want to get DLC at least to Dungeon to make it more replayable.  You do not need humans to play and the AI isn't that bad, except for their use of spells.  Spells aren't utilized very well by AI.  It will take time to learn the "When can I cast this system."  Spells do not have a natural or intuitive system for casting.  Even after 10-15 games you can still not cast them at right times always. Lots of options for which DLC to use each game and what parts of each can be used.  Know games can take 30 minutes to 3 hours to win.  What character you play and what cards you and the others get make a huge difference in the time involved.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												Love this game. Love it! I'm a board game/TTRPG junkie (multi-time Gen Con attendee). There's a ton of content here, and the game is fun and challenging at the same time. It's nice to be able to just jump into the digital edition without setup, and even with some AI that's not TOO bad. It does make a few boneheaded mistakes though.For instance I usually play with random characters against 3 AI. I had the Troll. I killed one of the other characters and forgot to loot ALL the items (my own fault, hit the button to quick) and the Devil's Minion CPU player swooped in and grabbed it all including the follower that reduces the Peril of Plane's requirements by 1 die. OMG. The Devil's Minion made to the the Crown of Command, because he made it there so early he only had 5 STR and 6 CRA. I got EXTREMELY lucky and grabbed the poltergiest as a follower on the right side of the outer region of the board. Along there was "The healer with 2 free heals " (thankfully I got turned to Good along the way!) and "The Shrine", next to them was the Forest. So since I could only move one space it was great that I could keep moving back and forth between these spaces healing myself and trying to bump up my craft at the Forest. I also had spells of one Counterspell, one Random, and one Temporal Warp. I was going to use the Temporal Warp when I finally started making my run to the Crown! I made a huge mistake by going into the Village and not realizing it ditched the Poltergiest! OH NO! Since I had 10 STR and 5 CRA, I decided to make a run for it. The Devil's Minion rolled BADLY on quite a few Crown spells. I luckily made my way all the way to the Crown with 11 STR from figting one monster along the way and cashing some in. So the Devil's Minion had 5 lives, I had 4. But I definitely had the upper hand from a mathematical standpoint. So what does the Devil's Minion do when he fights me, he picks STR!! WHAT IN THE. I was afraid it was going to be a race to 0 to see who could roll luck (he COULDN'T beat me in STR 11 vs 5, but he had a chance in CRA 5 vs 6). So I whittled him down to 1 health, and THEN he finally lets loose with a CRA attack and actually wins. I beat him the next turn.This is what I mean by the AI makes some poor decisions. What should have been a nail-biter, ended up being a big WHA? What is he doing?! Still love the game!!

												Although I never played the board game, I can easily attest to the fact that this game brings the worst out in yourself and your friends, which in itself leads to hilarious and memorable moments. That, coupled with the random nature of the game, is in my opinion its greatest strength, as it allows everybody to compete on an even level. The randomness might get frustrating in single player though and I clearly recommend that you band together and buy the four pack, so you have somebody to play with, because the social aspect of the game is half the experience.On the downside, the technical aspect of multiplayer matches does have some hiccups. I have experienced sync issues and game crashes a couple of times, which is aggravating when you are about to wrap up a game session, which easily runs in at about two hours. This shouldn’t keep you from buying the game if you have some friends around to play it with though.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Almost identcal to playing the board game with a few major exceptions. the most important being speed. A real life Talisman game can usually take up 6hrs. With the turn speed for the PC ramped up to 10 I finished my first game in 3hrs.  This is not a problem as playing well in games causes you to level up unlocking new stuff. Quite what I'm not yet sure as it will take more than one game to level up. The other major difference is price. A full set of Talisman with the expnasion will srt you back nearly £100 for the physical version.I do love my physichal set and this does lack the atmosphere of having some like minded mates round for a good boardgames session. But as an introduction to the game or as a way of killing the hours over the summer while your mates are on holiday this is highly recomended. Also if you have friends who play but dont live locally it is also possible to set up an online game over the web.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												Great game that deserves a serious look by every RPG, RTS fan. This game is as close to a perfect physical board game to video game as I've seen, and I have played 90% of all the board game ports. I can't recommend this game enough to at least put on your wishlist to wait for a sale if you don't want to buy the original price.Pros: good overall flow of the game, intuitive AI, the best board game port to dateCons: slight to minimal delay in the UI in the main menu/options screen that may turn off some playersI have this same version in the iOS format and both versions are identical to each other, with the PC exception having better animations overall. The game itself plays great and the computer AI really is impressive with the difference of behaviors each character and how they interact with the board. I have never played the board game, but after 50+ hours on the mobile version and purchasing the PC port I will be one day purchase the physical board game from my local hobby shop. One of my favorite things that was added to the video game is a chance to reroll dice that is called Fate. To me its the best mechanic to the game and in my opinion the most important. The game can be played in multiple ways to achieve the victory. It incorporates player vs player feel but games can be won by solely player vs environment while allying with other players (limited pvp encounters and purposedly avoiding other players on the board). Any fans of fantasy, saturday morning 1980s cartoons, dice rolling, and board games in general will appreciate this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Games Workshop released a fantasy board game called Talisman in 1983, for 2-6 players. I have an early second edition of the game from 1985. While I generally prefer games that rely more on skill than chance, this was one game that I’ve always really enjoyed, but often cursed the roll of the dice or a card draw. (The hate part of things relates to how long the game can go on for.)A while back, I received a copy of the digital version of the game. This version appears to have the same “board” as the 2nd edition, but I believe it’s based on Fantasy Flight Games “Revised 4th edition“, since the character and card images are the same. (Also, the expansions match.)For those that haven’t played the game (or don’t remember much) here’s a summary:The board layout is three circular regions – Outer, Middle and Inner. Each player selects a character (randomly) that has different starting stats and special abilities. Strength is used for physical combat, Craft for psychic combat. Players have a number of lives, and a bag of gold. In your turn, you roll a dice (d6) and move that many spaces (locations) around the board. Each location represents a place (such as) – plain, forest, wood, shrine, chapel, graveyard, tavern, village, city. Most locations require the drawing of an Adventure card, others have a dice roll to see what happens. The cards may be an enemy or monster to fight, an object that can be kept, a follower who may assist you, etc. Some may allow you to gain Strength, Craft, Life, or Spells. Combat is 1d6 + Strength (or Craft) + item/follower bonuses vs the same roll for the creature. A win means a trophy, else lose a life. Players build up their characters (increasing stats, buying/finding items, etc) and move towards the centre of the board, hopefully gaining a talisman along the way. In the inner region lies the Crown of Command, which is used to drain the life of all other players in order to win the game.My game box states playing time as “1 Hour plus” and I don’t think I’ve ever seen a game take less than two hours. (Playing the digital version with AI opponents is quicker than with real people, but still takes a while!) This is mostly because of the great amount of time required to build up a character to a level that can enter the Inner region and progress (without dying or being pushed back to middle/outer region). This, and the chance of losing nearly everything with a bad dice roll (or unlucky card draw) is the games biggest down-side. The game play is very much one based on chance. The only skill is in good use of items, spells, and special abilities. There is a lot of variety with characters and cards – it’s also a large board – so every game is very different.The two main “changes” that I’ve noted in the digital edition (compared to 2nd) are the Fate stat (which allows re-rolls, FANTASTIC addition!), and the ability to increase Craft by trading in defeated spirits (psychic combat monsters). In 2nd edition, you could only trade “strength using” monsters. (7 Str points of creatures for +1 character Strength)It’s extremely faithful to the board game. The graphics are very well done, and everything runs smoothly. You can play with 2 to 4 players, with those players being AI run, or actual people. The game speed can be adjusted, various “house rules” can be turned on/off, and it saves games. It’s really nice having the game track all your bonuses, and you can click on any board space to get detail on that location, as well as check what cards (objects and followers) any other player holds. It’s got a tutorial mode and good “help”. Overall, I’m very impressed and I can see myself playing a lot of this over the next month.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												All nostalgia about this being a faithful recreation of my favorite childhood board game, this is just plain fun. It's also a lot faster, not to mention cheaper, than tracking down a copy of the orginal game. Even the very rare, very costly expansion sets to the board game are available as DLC for the digital version. Simply put: if you like adventure board games, this is for you. Play by yourself against the AI, online, or even hotseat mode with your friends. *SPOILER* The Prophetess got nerfed in the digital version, which anyone familiar with the origanal game would agree was needed, as she was otherwise game-breakingly overpowered.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												If you are new to Talisman (like myself), you will find that it is an easy game to get into.  I haven't even read the instructions but after playing with others online, I am learning pretty quickly how to play this game.  It's a fun fantasy/strategy board game.  It isn't too complex and it's kind of luck-based. There is a low player-base, but I am always able to find a match without waiting too long.  The servers that people seem to play on are USA and Europe.  Another cool thing about this game is that other people can share their characters with you.  By this I mean that if you don't have the DLC, and the HOST of the game does, then the host of the game is able to share their characters with you and the other players in the game.  Also, if you have a bad internet connection and disconnect from the game, you are able to rejoin the match once you re-open the game. I bought this game during the Steam Summer Sale for only $4.49 and it was well worth it.  You should definitely buy this if you are into board games.

												I purchased the game through the Humble Bundle and so far I have been impressed. Online does have some issues. 1 play through online took about 3 hours and we had 3 total disconnects. Anyone interested in the game I would encourage to watch a few lets plays to get the hang of the rules and also to see if this is a game they will be interested in. If you do not have a group of friends to play the game with I would recomend staying away or using Steam or Reddit to find people to play with. The AI leaves much to desire. Anyone who is a fan of board games and have a few friends willing to play with then this game is worth the purchase and with these factors I would give the game a 7/10 in its current form. With more NET improvements and Spell casting changes to make it more intuative I could say my rating going higher.

content:

												I used to play the original Talisman board game with my parents when I was a child, so when I saw that it had been remade as an online-capable computer game, I knew I had to try it.  I got a four-pack, so that I could gift a copy to my parents and sister, and I have to say that it is pretty faithful to the original.  There are some minor glitches, made less minor by the fact that some of them can make it impossible to finish a game (making it necessary to start a new one), but it is a fun, semi-relaxed game to play, and provided a nice trip down memory lane for me.

												Game is a lot of fun, but man the bots are stupid.In one game Dwarf-bot, with an 'axe', 'bag of carrying', 'false grail' and 'shield', decided to make a raft 7 times in a row, only to discard it after each turn because he didn't have room to carry it (sorry to anyone not familiar with the game).Anyone who knows the 'bag of carrying' knows they can conceal extra items in there that don't count towards the max amount of items you can carry. content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												I'm not a fan of Games Workshop.  In fact, I don't like Games Workshop at all.  But this review is not about the company, but about this game.  I played Talisman when it first came out.  When I found out it was on Steam, I was intrigued.  When I picked it up with the Humble Bundle, I was interested in giving it a shot.I enjoy the game.  I enjoy running around the board, gathering power, and making a push for the crown, leaving everyone in my dust.  Yes, the game begins fairly random, but there is a strategy to the game, and if you know what you're doing, the game becomes less and less random as you shape your character into the champion (or horror) you want it to be.Some simple tactics:  1)  Get to the Warlock and try to get the Clockwork Owl as quickly as you can.  This turns your die rolls for movement into something you can control (since you can move your die roll or less after this).  2)  Get to the warlock and get the bag of holding.  Having 8 concealable slots to carry your most precious gear in is a good thing.  3)  Go to the warlock and get the orb of prophesy (or be lucky and draw the magic item which does similar).  This allows you to control your encounters.  Along the way you should be getting magic items or followers to pad out your abilities.  But once you have those three items (or heck, even just the first), you're able to control your fate fairly well, and can make the push to get to the middle of the board and win.The introduction of runestones is an interesting twist, as is having fate points.  Those both help to deter getting hosed early in the game, and I think they're a workable addition.  I plan on picking up the expansions.I give the Digital Edition of Talisman 4/5.
