content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Talisman: Digital Edition is a fun time killer if you have nothing to do for a hour or so.  It's convenient if you just want to relax, play a quick single player game and move onto to other things you need to do that afternoon.  There's plemty of expansions and alot of characters to choose from that keeps it interesting.On the downside, however, the game does have its flaws.    Spells not working when casted/que'd. Picking targets for spells sometimes doesn't work properly or is confusing.     Some cards don't work occasionally like, "Use this card before another players turn" where you'll try to use it but nothing happens and you just get a "dismiss" option only.   And my personal complaint is the computer player almost always rolls a "6"  and you'll get ten "1's" in a row which can be frustrating.Overall, it's still a fun game to play if you look past the flaws.   Catch it on sale.   Highly recommend getting the expansions (Dungeon, Highlands, etc) for it as well as it adds another level to the game.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Games Workshop released a fantasy board game called Talisman in 1983, for 2-6 players. I have an early second edition of the game from 1985. While I generally prefer games that rely more on skill than chance, this was one game that I’ve always really enjoyed, but often cursed the roll of the dice or a card draw. (The hate part of things relates to how long the game can go on for.)A while back, I received a copy of the digital version of the game. This version appears to have the same “board” as the 2nd edition, but I believe it’s based on Fantasy Flight Games “Revised 4th edition“, since the character and card images are the same. (Also, the expansions match.)For those that haven’t played the game (or don’t remember much) here’s a summary:The board layout is three circular regions – Outer, Middle and Inner. Each player selects a character (randomly) that has different starting stats and special abilities. Strength is used for physical combat, Craft for psychic combat. Players have a number of lives, and a bag of gold. In your turn, you roll a dice (d6) and move that many spaces (locations) around the board. Each location represents a place (such as) – plain, forest, wood, shrine, chapel, graveyard, tavern, village, city. Most locations require the drawing of an Adventure card, others have a dice roll to see what happens. The cards may be an enemy or monster to fight, an object that can be kept, a follower who may assist you, etc. Some may allow you to gain Strength, Craft, Life, or Spells. Combat is 1d6 + Strength (or Craft) + item/follower bonuses vs the same roll for the creature. A win means a trophy, else lose a life. Players build up their characters (increasing stats, buying/finding items, etc) and move towards the centre of the board, hopefully gaining a talisman along the way. In the inner region lies the Crown of Command, which is used to drain the life of all other players in order to win the game.My game box states playing time as “1 Hour plus” and I don’t think I’ve ever seen a game take less than two hours. (Playing the digital version with AI opponents is quicker than with real people, but still takes a while!) This is mostly because of the great amount of time required to build up a character to a level that can enter the Inner region and progress (without dying or being pushed back to middle/outer region). This, and the chance of losing nearly everything with a bad dice roll (or unlucky card draw) is the games biggest down-side. The game play is very much one based on chance. The only skill is in good use of items, spells, and special abilities. There is a lot of variety with characters and cards – it’s also a large board – so every game is very different.The two main “changes” that I’ve noted in the digital edition (compared to 2nd) are the Fate stat (which allows re-rolls, FANTASTIC addition!), and the ability to increase Craft by trading in defeated spirits (psychic combat monsters). In 2nd edition, you could only trade “strength using” monsters. (7 Str points of creatures for +1 character Strength)It’s extremely faithful to the board game. The graphics are very well done, and everything runs smoothly. You can play with 2 to 4 players, with those players being AI run, or actual people. The game speed can be adjusted, various “house rules” can be turned on/off, and it saves games. It’s really nice having the game track all your bonuses, and you can click on any board space to get detail on that location, as well as check what cards (objects and followers) any other player holds. It’s got a tutorial mode and good “help”. Overall, I’m very impressed and I can see myself playing a lot of this over the next month.

												All nostalgia about this being a faithful recreation of my favorite childhood board game, this is just plain fun. It's also a lot faster, not to mention cheaper, than tracking down a copy of the orginal game. Even the very rare, very costly expansion sets to the board game are available as DLC for the digital version. Simply put: if you like adventure board games, this is for you. Play by yourself against the AI, online, or even hotseat mode with your friends. *SPOILER* The Prophetess got nerfed in the digital version, which anyone familiar with the origanal game would agree was needed, as she was otherwise game-breakingly overpowered.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												If you are new to Talisman (like myself), you will find that it is an easy game to get into.  I haven't even read the instructions but after playing with others online, I am learning pretty quickly how to play this game.  It's a fun fantasy/strategy board game.  It isn't too complex and it's kind of luck-based. There is a low player-base, but I am always able to find a match without waiting too long.  The servers that people seem to play on are USA and Europe.  Another cool thing about this game is that other people can share their characters with you.  By this I mean that if you don't have the DLC, and the HOST of the game does, then the host of the game is able to share their characters with you and the other players in the game.  Also, if you have a bad internet connection and disconnect from the game, you are able to rejoin the match once you re-open the game. I bought this game during the Steam Summer Sale for only $4.49 and it was well worth it.  You should definitely buy this if you are into board games.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Talisman: Digital Edition is a faithful update to the old school Games-Workshop Talisman board game.  The game is actually based on a newer iteration by Fantasy Flight games however much of the original feel is still there.  The digital implementation of the game features an intuitive interface, crisp artwork, and balance improvements that don’t allow a Chaos Warrior to run rampant across your game board and on top of competing players.  The only real downside is that the AI is not very good and doesn’t try to win the game –however the game plays well in multiplayer and is really a blast.  If you want to play an old school early 1990’s board game online, love games workshop, or just want to turn your buddies into a toad and curb stomp them . . . this game is for you!

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												A fantasy boardgame turned digital. Very fun with friends, but the UI/engine is a little buggy. Online multiplayer can cause disconnects sometimes, but luckily there's a fast and easy "retry" function which automatically remakes the game and starts at the last turn played.Players pick from a pool of characters and take turns traveling around a spiraled board with three regions (four if you have the expansion) where each space on the board has it's own description of an action that affects play. The characters each have their own stats and abilities which makes re-playability very high. It feels a little unbalanced as some characters feel better than others since they can snowball given their unique abilities, where others don't seem to take off until deep into the game. As time in the game progresses players collect monsters as trophies, collect cards, gold, or battle each other to collect stat points. The objective is to get enough stat points to go past the required spaces on the board and get to the center space to claim victory.It's a game of dicerolls, but having more stats or inventory cards will improve your odds by a huge margin. There are weapons that increase your strength or craft, armor that will let you re-roll to save yourself from taking damage, items that give you magic spells, etc... but it still comes down to the luck of the dice. It's very frustrating when you're getting beat down, but very satisfying when you're doing the beating.In short, the game is good fun with friends, but I can't imagine playing it by myself.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Okay, right off the bat, this is an awesome game to play! So much fun to level up your character, gaining strength and craft to fight enemies with. The object of the game is to reach "the crown of command" in the center of the board. However this is not so simple. You will have to go on different quests throughout the game to gain an object known as a "Talisman" to get the various places on the board. You will need one as you travel from the middle region of the board to the center region. However many things could happen between getting one and getting through to the center region. A player could fight you and kill you. A witch, bear or demon could spawn on you and destroy powerful or useful items you're carrying. The worst? Being turned into a toad. This is where all your items are dropped in the space you have turned into the toad. While playing as a toad, other players can pick up your items. It's a very challenging game and extremely time consuming. The 8 hours i have played.. 6 of them is just one full game of talisman, where unfortunately i did not win! I have the actual board game too and the digital version helped me learn it better as it gives you tutorials on your playthrough. Of course these can be turned off! If you are a fan of fantasy, board games and strategy then this one is definately for you! For what it is, i give it an 8/10. The game itself is excellent, but as i say you need a LOT of time spare if you're wanting to finish a game!

Spells do not have a natural or intuitive system for casting.  Even after 10-15 games you can still not cast them at right times always. Lots of options for which DLC to use each game and what parts of each can be used.  Know games can take 30 minutes to 3 hours to win.  What character you play and what cards you and the others get make a huge difference in the time involved.

Posted: September 12, 2015
												Love this game. Love it! I'm a board game/TTRPG junkie (multi-time Gen Con attendee). There's a ton of content here, and the game is fun and challenging at the same time. It's nice to be able to just jump into the digital edition without setup, and even with some AI that's not TOO bad. It does make a few boneheaded mistakes though.For instance I usually play with random characters against 3 AI. I had the Troll. I killed one of the other characters and forgot to loot ALL the items (my own fault, hit the button to quick) and the Devil's Minion CPU player swooped in and grabbed it all including the follower that reduces the Peril of Plane's requirements by 1 die. OMG. The Devil's Minion made to the the Crown of Command, because he made it there so early he only had 5 STR and 6 CRA. I got EXTREMELY lucky and grabbed the poltergiest as a follower on the right side of the outer region of the board. Along there was "The healer with 2 free heals " (thankfully I got turned to Good along the way!) and "The Shrine", next to them was the Forest. So since I could only move one space it was great that I could keep moving back and forth between these spaces healing myself and trying to bump up my craft at the Forest. I also had spells of one Counterspell, one Random, and one Temporal Warp. I was going to use the Temporal Warp when I finally started making my run to the Crown! I made a huge mistake by going into the Village and not realizing it ditched the Poltergiest! OH NO! Since I had 10 STR and 5 CRA, I decided to make a run for it. The Devil's Minion rolled BADLY on quite a few Crown spells. I luckily made my way all the way to the Crown with 11 STR from figting one monster along the way and cashing some in. So the Devil's Minion had 5 lives, I had 4. But I definitely had the upper hand from a mathematical standpoint. So what does the Devil's Minion do when he fights me, he picks STR!! WHAT IN THE. I was afraid it was going to be a race to 0 to see who could roll luck (he COULDN'T beat me in STR 11 vs 5, but he had a chance in CRA 5 vs 6). So I whittled him down to 1 health, and THEN he finally lets loose with a CRA attack and actually wins. I beat him the next turn.This is what I mean by the AI makes some poor decisions. What should have been a nail-biter, ended up being a big WHA? What is he doing?! Still love the game!!

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Although I never played the board game, I can easily attest to the fact that this game brings the worst out in yourself and your friends, which in itself leads to hilarious and memorable moments. That, coupled with the random nature of the game, is in my opinion its greatest strength, as it allows everybody to compete on an even level. The randomness might get frustrating in single player though and I clearly recommend that you band together and buy the four pack, so you have somebody to play with, because the social aspect of the game is half the experience.On the downside, the technical aspect of multiplayer matches does have some hiccups. I have experienced sync issues and game crashes a couple of times, which is aggravating when you are about to wrap up a game session, which easily runs in at about two hours. This shouldn’t keep you from buying the game if you have some friends around to play it with though.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Almost identcal to playing the board game with a few major exceptions. the most important being speed. A real life Talisman game can usually take up 6hrs. With the turn speed for the PC ramped up to 10 I finished my first game in 3hrs.  This is not a problem as playing well in games causes you to level up unlocking new stuff. Quite what I'm not yet sure as it will take more than one game to level up. The other major difference is price. A full set of Talisman with the expnasion will srt you back nearly £100 for the physical version.I do love my physichal set and this does lack the atmosphere of having some like minded mates round for a good boardgames session. But as an introduction to the game or as a way of killing the hours over the summer while your mates are on holiday this is highly recomended. Also if you have friends who play but dont live locally it is also possible to set up an online game over the web.

												This is by far one of the saltiest games to play with your friends.  I just got out of a 6 hour game with five of my friends only to have it crash when almost everyone died. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												If you're a fan of boardgames then this is great. It has a lot of different characters and offers quite a lot of gameplay variety, especially if you have the expansion packs. Best to buy the season pass on sale.Gameplay wise, you pick a character, travel around the map battling monsters and completing quests in order to increase your character's strength or craft (magic) score. Eventually, you'll be able to move into the inner region to reach the crown of command, where, you might complete the generic victory condition or a special victory condition (if you have this feature turned on).It's fun, especially with friends. It does take awhile to play though, and all the extra content might seem a bit jarring. 7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												4 hours in to a game, one turn away from winning, and you get pulled out of the middle and robbed. 3 hours in to a game and your friend turns you in to a frog and kills you. 2 hours in and you're on your 4th character because nothing will go right. You get Talisman'd a lot in this game... why would anyone want to play this? Cause its a heck of a lot of fun. You spend the game raising your strength and craft, the two stats you use to fight battles. Talisman is one big journey to level your character up enough to go challenge whatever is in the middle of the board. Sometimes you might have to fight a boss to win the game, other times you might have to steal everyone's items, or you might even vote to see if the persons worthy. It's the mix of endings, cards, and characters that make the game interesting.I highly recommend playing with actual people, while the computer has decent decision making skills it is far from perfect.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												If you enjoyed playing the Talisman Board Game in real life and really want to play it again: get this game!Otherwise, do not!This is a pretty good emulation of the board game. HOWEVER, it does suffer from slowness and could really use a few settings to quicken up the game. Additionally there are some problems with crashing every once in a while.If the developers are listening please implement a way to skip through dice rolls in which there is no way for there is no way to win or lose. For example, if my roll of one dice +5, resulted in an 10, then the dice roll of the other person is just a dice roll +2 then there is no need for that dice roll to be rolled...Bottom line, good emulation of game, but suffers from some serious slowness and crashing. Only get if you want to enjoy some Talisman nostalgia.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Talisman, with all the expansion content enabled, is a very fun game with an expansive, adventurous feel that supports a variety of diverse play styles.  Without the expansion content enabled, it's a much more straightforward and less interesting experience.  The UI could also benefit from some adjustments, as it's sometimes difficult to click spells before the game moves past the point where they're legal to play, and at times you're forced to make a decision without the ability to click around to examine details of the game state... issues which can both be largely mitigated by familiarity and careful attentiveness, but which will hopefully be remedied in the future.All of this together makes for a game that's a lot of fun with a bit of investment, but which does not make a good first impression.  I almost asked for a refund, but I'm very glad I didn't.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												This is a great game, I never heard of Talisman until i saw my friends playing the steam version, and I now play it almost once a week if not more with them. I would reccommend this game to anyone who just wants to have a good time with friends, but if youre looking for good gameplay on your own... unless you really just want some nostalgia This game isn't for you.Pros---------------Good time waster with friends-nostalgic for you long time Talisman players-interesting interactions-you can laugh at the horrible AICons---------------Horribly buggy at times... many of which are game breaking (for example followers or spells that let you choose what your reroll will be will often reroll your second dice if you have 2 to choose from, or if you visit a shop and dont have enough money for an item the game just doesnt know what to do and breaks)-purely based on RNG very few times is decision making or skill going to win you the game because 90% of this game is pure luck unless you get some crazy powerful items from some of the expansions (cough cough clockwork owl) or if you get characters that can see the top of the deck like sage or spy.-kinda already stated as a pro but the AI is horrible, some might see that as a good thing because they can give you good items for bad ones or engage in battles they clearly cant win or dont use some items because they forget to... but otherwise its kinda stupid-DLC for the game can be pretty pricey, if you buy the game and all expansions (not including the standalone characters) currently available it will go for roughly $45 or you can make it $75 and buy the season pass which includes all current and future DLC except one that was sold for charity.TL;DR: The game is great to hang out with friends especially if you cant get together im person easily (or at all) But if you want everything its gonna be quite the money drop, the game is also horribly buggy and seems to lack some quality of life features like cancel buttons for most actions (shopping or spell casting for example) but if you can get past the bugs and horrible AI, then its a good time with your friends guarenteed!

												This is an Excellent game, I searched this one out after hearing about the game, that originally was played as a table top now recreated as a digital board game. content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												I'm sure that this is a really good game 73% of players have said so plus, I would love to pick up some of the DLC that are on sale this week, I just wish I could play it. Unfortunately, it will only run for about 3- 5 turns then it freezes not the whole PC just the game and I have to ctrl-alt-del out. I am well in excess of the recommended PC specs plus, have tried all the available fixes on the forums here and elsewhere and asked many questions.I reported the problem to Nomad Games however, as there is no crash report generated when it freezes they have very little to work on except my PC specs and my list of tried but failed fixes.Apparently I have logged 2.4 hours play, this is NOT actual play but running the program just to try out various "fixes" .I have tried every fix I can find on line plus, turning off background process or varying game play combinations that I can think of that could be causing the problem, add my research time to find an answer and I must have spent at least 5 hours on this game without actually playing it.Perhaps with the soon expected patch it will finally work for me.I'm very disappointed so far, especially as I will miss out on the current DLC sale, the only consolation for me is that I bought the base game during a previous sale.Why a thumbs up? Well, I can't really not recommend or criticize it because I haven't played it yet plus, the freezing problem seems to be a very rare occurrence for the majority and it would appear that most of those who had the problem found on line answers that unfortunately did not work for me.I will revise this review if I ever get this game to run.UPDATEI have no idea what has changed but, the game has been running without problems for over an hour. I'm still somewhat confused over parts of the gameplay although the tutorial has helped. I guess i'll just have to read the game manual again as well.It looks like this is going to be a fun game based on my experience so far with an understanding of gameplay around say 75% I would give the game at least 7 out of 10 andf I have the feeling that after more playing that score will increase.I originally bought this as a precursor to buying the board game if I enjoyed it and I have a strong feeling that I will be buying the board game as well.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Very happy to have this game on pc.  I still own 2 versions of the original board game which I have played countless times.  As such I can confirm the game rules are superbly accurate to the original, making this game a must for all Talisman fans.On occasion, it can be difficult to use an ability or specific card during your turn (within the time limit given) as the game will not remind or encourage you to check your inventory lists, so you need to pay attention.This is a rare occurance, however, dependant on character chosen rather than any particular oversight due to the game design.  There are plenty of new characters to purchase as well as three of the original six expansion packs already released.  Dice roll for me is depressingly unlucky (just as it always was for my board games) so i find the gameplay quite difficult.  Animations are colourful and the addition of runestones and customisable rules keeps the game interesting. You can even save your progress on multiple games and come back to them when you want.I highly recommend this game already and will love it even more when the Timescape expansion is added.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												I wholeheartedly recommend this game. especially with the season pass. there are so many more characters and new stuff added in the season pass that it adds almost unlimited replayability. even just the base game has a ton of content to be worth the $15. it takes them a while to put out new DLC in the season pass, but by now, almost all of it has been released. i don't mind how long it takes them to update the game and add the new content because the content that gets added is always worth the wait. tons of endings, tons of ways to play. it's got local multiplayer so you can play with anyone who might be in the room. plus they recently increased the maximum number of players from 4 to 6. depending on what endings you choose and/or how you decide to play the game (what features/options you decide to turn off) can affect the length of the game. some games can be over in less than half an hour and others can take 3 or 4 hours. i've played almost all the characters at this point and i have to say that i'm impressed that they can really change the way you play the game. there's a monk who can add his craft to his strength but can't use weapons. there's a minstrel who can tame animals and add their strength to his. there's a warrior who can use 2 weapons instead of just one. every character feels unique and changes the way you might play the game. it's hard to describe what a typical game will contain as the large number of items, enemies, spells, and characters make every game different. honestly, the biggest problem i have with this game is the dice rolling. all the dice rolls are predetermined the moment you start up the game. for example, if it's your turn and you roll two dice and one is a 4 and one is a 2, then you move and land on a space and draw a monster from the deck and roll a 5 and the monster rolls a 3-then you quit the game and start it up again but just roll 1 dice or use an item/spell to move and get a different monster, all the dice rolls you just had will play out in that exact order. if you get that 4, you'll roll a 2 in the monster battle and the monster will roll a 5 and if you use a fate to reroll, you'll get that 3. it essentially allows you to know the future and what numbers your enemies will get on their turns. i don't know if they can, but i hope they can fix it.Edit:i think what draws me to this game the most is the fact that you can play with the same character against the same enemy characters time and time again and every single game will play out differently. sure, you might win every time, but what you do along the way will be different every time regardless of what characters are in the game.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												tl;dr I didn't like it.Pre-Disclaimer: Please don't comment to tell me I'm wrong, refer to the disclaimer (next).Disclaimer: I'm sure I'll get somewhere > 10% "people thought this was helpful" with me for this review... but I have to post it anyways. Reviews are people's opinions. And like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, everyone's got one and they're all♥♥♥♥♥♥anyways. So here I go...I could not get into this game at all. I've never played the board game or heard of the franchise until I started playing. The pop up rules and tips and hints, etc go on and on and on. They do almost nothing to actually help you play the game, so much as they just blather on about this and that and so on and so forth.. kinda like my review..Anyways. the graphics are a board game that's poorly drawn, with hard to see squares (but you figure out that everything is a square, and there is no point in them anyways). The characters are poorly drawn. The animations are basically cards flipping and moving around on the screen and a die (or sometimes two dice) rolling. So that's about a 2/10.The audio consists of fanfare queues and other nonsensical sounds that notify you that something is happening even though nothing really is.. and you get to hear the sound of a die rolling a lot. If I wanted to hear dice rolling a lot I'd sit at my table, alone and roll real dice. so sound is a 1/10.The gameplay is as I stated above, and it's kinda glitchy. I played with AI opponents and they'd get a card, then roll a die or two and then they're in battle, then they roll more die, then draw a card, etc. then it would be my turn and I'd roll a die, land on a square and then end turn. I don't think that's a glitch but when you play every round and each AI is doing 3-4 actions and you get 1 (or maybe 2 if you're really lucky)... it just feels off and/or unfair. Then when you look at turns and actions in general, they're rather uninspired and not fun. there's also no free will in the game (other than an option or two every couple turns) so you could literally set up the game to play 4 AI players and no user and get the same amount of enjoyment from it. Plus it's a luck based game so no matter what you choose, almost nothing is affected. so gameplay is a 0/10. So totaling up our 30 point score here, the game gets a 3. out of 30. 10%.. 1/10. F-------. Yeah this game wasn't for me. Feel free to mark this as not helpful. I've heard that's the "I disagree" button, right? whatever.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Loved the Boardgame, hate the incompetent QA on this computer game though.  The UI bugs break the rules of the game.Lots of games have a few bugs here and there.  And there are some bugs that are only slightly annoying - or make you have to perform workarounds - but after just 2 days I'm encountering bugs in *THIS* game that actually cause the game to cheat the player out of their win.  Not in the usual sense, but in the sense that the user interface breaks and fails to let you take the actions the rules say you're supposed to be able to take.For 2 whole months there was a longstanding bug that if any AI player tries to cast the Weakness spell, the UI freezes and gets caught in a loop unable to continue the game so you have to start a new game.  And if you have the Weakness spell in the deck, and are playing against 3 AI players, then the chance of this happening at some point during the game is actually pretty high.  They had this problem reported for over 2 months and didn't fix it until just yesterday.So now I try again.  And run into another rules-cheating bug that stole my shot at winning the game away.  The HERMIT (the guy who gives a talisman to the first player to land on him) appeared in the Plain of Peril.  I open the Portal of Power, which puts me on the Plain of Peril where I'm planning to interact with the Hermit and get that talisman (a necessary item to be allowed to win the game), and the user interface doesn't have a provision for how to let you interact with cards on that space - it doesn't let you.  So the hermit is effectively a dead card when it appears there, which is definitely not how it's supposed to work.  By this point in the game other means of getting talismans were too far away and I wasn't going to be able to get one in time before another AI player would win.  Had I known the game was lying when it said the HERMIT would give a talisman to the first player who landed there, I might have tried a different tactic.  As it was, in this game it was too late.The game was basicaly too buggy and not ready for release yet.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												Let me say that any faithful copy of an old board game wins my immediate approval.  Tailisman is a faithful copy of the original and is a lot of good clean fun and very retro.  I recommend it to anyone that likes munckin and games workshop.I have issuse with this title for two reasons 1) PriceThis game is overpriced as all hell.  It's an old game with a niche audience, but remastering it should not entail an 80$ item.  If you are going to buy this game, then wait for a very favorable sale.  The DLC is also priced in such a way that it should never be purchased by anyone.2)AI I wasn't able to get my friends together for games and enemy AI is quite poor.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												What a pointless game. I've won this game nearly every time I played and I never left with a feeling of satisfaction. The interface of this game is atrocious. You can never make moves efficiently and half the time it is not clear how to use the cards you possess. And pray to the gods that you or your opponents never lose connection temporarily. The worst case scenario- the games takes a dump and everything goes to hell; the best case scenario- the atrocious AI takes over and immediate proceeds to ram as many items as it can into its own eyeballs in an attempt to impress the other players with its edgy suicide performance art. Really this is a terrible video game implementation of a terrible board game. I've yet to play a game that lasted less than 90min and most have lasted at least 3hrs. It takes no skill to win and the game frequently misinterprets spells or just plain bugs out and hamstrings the front-runner. All games tend toward every player colluding to ensure a swift end to the experience. How can anyone love such an RNG heavy, tedious piece of garbage. Even if you want a long-form RPG-style board game experience (and why would you) there are so  many better ones. Buy this game if you are a masochist. Buy this game for your friends if you are human trash.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This is a near perfect recreation of one of my favorite board games ever. I used to play this game all the time IRL, and I LOVE it, but now that a lot of my RL friends have moved away, this allows us all to keep in touch and still play games together.The game's not for everyone, it's god a heafty dose of luck involved in winning, and sometimes the game can be downright cruel. But it's epic, it's involved, it's got plenty of strategy, and absolutely boatloads of replayability. And the online matchmaking seems to be pretty stable most of the time (only ever had an issue just once).So yeah, for 74.98, you're getting every expansion for the game ever (with the exception of the Shaman Character, who's 1.99 and supports charity with purchase), which is a stellar deal considering each expansion is between 24.99 and 39.99 in real life and the base game is 49.99 if I'm not mistaken. And if you can get it on a sale, hell, even better! :D Totally worth the asking price, great game, can't recommend it enough! :D

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												A neat digital rendition of a Talisman tabletop game. Unlike the "prologue" version, which is oriented towards the single-player experience, this one is primarily multiplayer, local or online.In case you have never played the tabletop version, this game is somewhat like an RPG Monopoly. Dice-based, with some strategic decision making, but with few of those qualities that most gamers look for.Not much of a depth to it, but the replay value is quite high. The rules are rather customisable and you may finish a run rather quickly.The game does have occasional bugs (some spells can't be thrown and there are problems with Steam overlay compatibility in Win 7), but seeing as it was published recently, I expect the flaws to be ironed out rather soon.While this is not going to be anyone's GOTY (you should get it during a sale or in a bundle), I recommend it for those chillout evenings with your family and friends.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												What a worthless, drooling mess of a game.  The interface is incredibly clunky-- often it's confusing or outright lies about what will happen (cancel, dismiss, buying items, etc).  It was never clear how to use certain abilities and we often lost battles because it wouldn't explain how things would add up once we entered combat (we never figured it out).  It frequently disconnected one player and kept reconnecting him as the wrong player before kicking him again; the CPU sold off his items while he tried to get back in.For the 4.5 hours we spent playing, it was a long slog of fighting the interface for not a lot of fun.  Stick with the physical board game, it's actually functional.

												Ah-mazing. A pretty good way to play the game without having to take 30minutes to set it up! It'll take some time still and there is a bit of a learning curve with the digital interface (how cards work, when in the turn order they should be used, etc.) but thats hardly a problem. number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												This game is fun, but only if you have the correct mindset: sit back in your chair and relax, maybe pop a beer and most of all, play with your friends and socialize. The randomness makes it really hard to have control of the game and it can be infuriating to spend half an hour to try to move into a specific space that is necessary in order to move forward towards winning the game. Another thing to keep in mind is that a single game takes several hours to complete.The game gets pretty dull already after one game and I really recommend that you invest in some DLC in order to make it more interesting. A good starting point is to buy the Highlands expansion and The Dungeon Expansion and if you want to live dangeroulsy: the Reaper expansion.  If you want to shorten the game length (and don't want to grind) it might be a good idea to buy the Runestone deck. I've never tried any of the DLC that modifies the victory condition, so keep that in mind if you listen to my recommendations.I've played the tabletop version of this game and have about 10 hours of in game time divided on two Steam accounts at the time of writing this review. Now to the implementation: the game is extremely buggy. You can play  a whole game without issues, but it gets really irritating when the bugs appear. All cards don't work as they should and during my last game we had to restart it twice because we were unable to do any actions. The AI is stupid and I don't recommend this game if you plan to play it alone offline.So do I recommend this game? Although it's glitchy it's not unplayable. It's fun with the right people and it's an OK way to waste some time, but it's really not for everyone. So yes, if you are OK with all the downsides I stated I think that it's a good buy!

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Roll and move now on a PC.Talisman: Digital edition is a PC implementation of tabletop board game Talisman. In it you will take a role of one of many adventures and embark on an adventure. Roll dice to move, pick a direction and deal with the consequences. Many characters have special powers that you can utilize in one way or another to make achieving your goals a bit quicker. Talisman came out a long time and as many old games it has it’s share of issues that modern board games have learned to deal with. However like old games it also has a big fan base. Talisman: Digital edition is for better or worse a faithful representation of the board game. But as digital board games go it is quite well done. You are able to save your progress without occupying a whole table. You can play with your friends that are spread across the globe. And you can play by yourself if you don’t have any friends to play it. If you buy season pass that gives you access to all the dlc, of which Talisman has many, it will save you quite a bit of shelf space as well. Most of the issues with Talisman: Digital edition come inherited from the board game. That means it can take forever to finish a game and is quite unbalanced and a lot depends on a roll of a die. Added to that are a few AI issues where computer controlled players can get stuck in a loop of selling and buying swords or make actions that are not quite optimal. Dad rating: FineYou can save only on your turn. But you can pause the game during computer opponent turn.Some of the art on some cards can be a bit scary but it’s always static images that you could see in a book or a board game.Talisman is not my favorite board game. But I do like board games and it’s good to see some of them cross over to PC world. With digital implementation of board games they usually fall short because playing with physical components is so much better. In Talisman: Digital edition a lot of the hassle of playing with real board game is removed and that’s why I recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Worst board game I've ever playedI've played dozens of, if not over one hundred board and card games in my life. It's my favorite hobby when I can gather friends. Most of my income comes from tabletop games as well. Still, this is by far the most broken, dumb, and luck-dependent game I've ever played, not to mention it has player elimination in the late game, which might stretch for hours and hours and hours.I had heard about Talisman before, but never got the chance to play it. I ended up getting it on Steam recently to play it later. Also, after reading good reviews and trying the solo mode (the other app), I thought: "It looks dense, but nice after you get used to it". I even decided to get the Season Pass during last summer sales--oh, how I regret...Indeed Talisman gets slightly better overtime, after you get used to it. But in the end, it's a bad game, made worse in every aspect I could find. I ended up playing one match with a friend plus 2 AI's. One of them (Martyr) started off nicely, them the other AI (Assassin) and I (Sorceress) started catching up, until the Assassin made it to the end, trying to kill us off. Martyr was really close, but she got really, really bad rolls, despite she had built up pretty well, and she was the first to be elimnated, despite having dominated the entire game. My friend was next. Then, I spent DOZENS of turns surviving the Assassins attacks, not being able to reach him in any way. I couldn't get in because there were no amulets available, and I couldn't drop my quest (to get another one), which was to hurt another character, in order to maybe get a Talisman, because the only character in the game was out of reach. So I quit the game with 6 life, because I was tired of just surviving, not being able to do anything against it.The only pro in this game was getting a friend to laugh at it together, because Talisman is just ridiculous with all the luck-fest (and those who deny it have either been away from better, modern, and more balanced board games, or are just blind fans.... or both). The cons: too much luck (you roll dice for EVERYTHING), INSANELY slow, even with AI on top speed, broken mechanics, very unbalanced, takes way too long (almost 2 hours had gone by when it felt like the game was finally starting)... Not to mention broken achievements on top of that.To sum it all up, stay as far away from it as possible! Go buy an actual board game to play with friends. Or pick ANY OTHER board or card game on Steam, because you have a very, VERY high chance (I'd almost bet on 100%) of getting something better.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												A pretty simple and straightforward, yet classic board game about choosing whether to go right or left - and that statement really isn't that far from the truth. I don't mind it myself because it can be really enjoyable to play with your friends and in my opinion that's what's most important about these type of games.But when you're making a video game adaptation of a board game, you have to somehow compensate for the lack of physical interaction between the players and the social part of it - by making the game experience much smoother, faster, more manageable (simplifying the things that the players have to do mechanically - taking away all of the mess with tokens and cards etc.) and approachable.And this is the standard that I expect from every board game adaptation like this - this is something that is pretty much must be if there's any point in hoping that one would play it longer than 2 game sessions.And this is where this title fails - the UI is really, really clunky, a lot of interactions seem not to work as expected; not to mention some pretty annoying bugs that we've tackled very early on into the game. These are the basic things that the game should provide, and while I find the existence of bots really helpful (when someone suddenly has to go somewhere or just got really tired of the game, he can leave without spoiling the fun for everyone), this is not really enough to compensate for the rest of the issues this game has.The game itself is quite fun, as I said, but the board game original is the one that should be praised - the digital edition is very mediocre and is, as it seems to be, a superficial, hastily made, badly playtested piece of programming crap, and for that, thumbs down.

												I own every expansion for the physical version of talisman and am sorely dissapointed with the digital version.  The game is a buggy cash grab.  Crashing randomly and not giving you achievements.   Only a few of the actual expansions from the physical game have been made available with the developers deciding to opt for making individual characters(which i have been told now by someone with access to the dev build were just reworked characters that didn't make it into the original games that were just rebalanced which is even LAZIER than if they had created them from scratch) that cost roughly half as much as an ENTIRE EXPANSION!  for reference each expansion comes with 4 characters as well as roughly 100 new cards to add to your game.  The whole thing  is designed to milk your cash.  Nowhere near as enjoyable as the board game. Do not purchase this game. Especially avoid the season pass as who knows what new and incredibly lazy ways they will attempt to exploit their customers or if they will finish at all.    The physical game will be yours forever and doesn't require an online community that was already dying off when i got disgusted with the way this game was being mishandled.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												NOTE: This review is based entirely on games playing as a single player against 3 AI opponents.The game is in general fun. Yes, it's buggy. Yes, sometimes the AI makes idiotic (sometimes incomprehensible) choices. I am giving this game a bad review based on one thing:The "Random" spell.The number of games I've had completely upended by this one spell is ludicrous. I never got the chance to play the original board game, but if it were up to me, I would have pulled this spell out of any games I played with other people. The radical swings it causes either totally ruin the game, or extends the length of the game to the point where it is agonizing.If radical, late-game shifts in power balance are ok with you, then I can recommend this game. For myself this is a rage-quit offense (especially in a single player situation).

Posted: November 27, 2014
												This is a faithful recreation of the boardgame, no question. Simple roll and move, random card draw, limited decision making, like a slightly cooler version of Monopoly. The AI seems good at times but ultimately falls flat and gets caught in un productive loops. For example, The wizard had an axe and was in the forest so he made a raft to cross the river, this put him over his item limit however, so he had to discard an item, naturally he chose the raft he just made. every turn until I killed him. If you are looking for a faithful reproduction of a pretty bad boardgame, this will fit the bill nicely. If you're looking for a faithful reproduction of a good board game, try Space Hulk, Carcassonne, or Ticket to ride.

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												I remember countless hours I spent playing "Talisman" when I was a teenager. I loved how you could travel through the different realms and get more and more powerful. The different additional boards such as the City, the Dungeon and the Timescape added so much to this game. Especially the Timescape addition, with its Warhammer 40K science fiction theme was brilliant.When I first saw the digital edition, I remembered those great hours of joy I had as a teen and bought the Gold Pack. Unfortunately, the digital adaptation turned out to be extremely boring and lackluster. The additional sets are only integrated with new cards and, in the case of the Dungeon or the City, with one additional region on the main board, not with an entire board itself. There's no delving into the streets of the City with all its dangers and possibilities; there's no Dungeon to enter; and, which is at least to me the biggest issue, there's no Timescape with all its weird possiblities, deadly adversaries and powerful artifacts. I really don't understand all those comments who say that this adaptation is faithful. It seems as if those guys have never played the original board game with all its expansion sets. Of course, you can say that the developers are still working on the game, but they've already published the Dungeon as well as the City expansion, and both of them are very poor adaptations of the original expansion sets. And this isn't simply a case of different subjective tastes or different valid opinions: just take a look at the original board game and its expansions, and then take a look at how these were adapted in the digital version. If someone wants to tell me that this is a faithful adaptation, then he's no idea what he's talking about.The AI isn't really convincing. It searches for the most direct way to reach the central region, making the player to rush forward in order to beat it. In the two games I completed, the AI characters killed off each other, so I had only to deal with one weakened survivor.There are only a handful of characters who are useful, so most players probably won't care for the other characters at all. This was an issue with the original Talisman as well, but each addition had some new useful characters that the digital version doesn't have. The Dungeon and City boards had some mediocre but useful characters to choose from, and the Timescape addition came with such great characters such as the Space Pirate, the Space Marine, the Astropath, the Chainsaw Warrior or the Cyborg. All of them were powerful additions that gave the player a greater rooster of useful characters to choose from. However, the digital version doesn't have them and leaves the player with only one or two characters to choose from; the others are just underpowered rubbish.I haven't played the multiplayer version, but I've heard only bad things about it, so, even if I did find anyone who plays it, I wouldn't try it.Damn, I really wanted this to be a good game. I really wanted to give a smaller studio a chance, even if this meant that I paid a lot of money for an unfinished product, quasi at face value. How I was disappointed! Admittedly, the developers come up with new content on a regular basis, but it's just not convincing at all. This is one of my all-time favorite board games, and they turned it into a dull, uninspirated, luke-warm rehash.CONCLUSIONIf you haven't heard of Talisman before, don't waste your money on the digital version. Better try to find the old board game, gather some friends and play it. If you, like me, loved the original board game, then don't make the mistake to waste your money on the digital version. Grab the old board game, get some cold beer, try to find some surviving friends who still have time to spend an evening with an old school board game, and enjoy it.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												This is by far the worst game that I have ever played in my life, it is nothing more then a series of dice rolls, in fact I think you would have more fun if you spent 2 hours mindlessly rolling dice then play this game. the first game I attempted to play I was doing great almost going to hit the last space, but an A.I characters cast a spell on me that turned me into a toad, in which I lost all my items, then the next turn he stole all of my items, which after that I restarted the game. to which I was treated to the most mindless and boring experience of my life, I quickly was able to aquire enough items to make it to the last square, instead of winning like I assumed I would, all it did was trap me and force me to cast a spell to kill the other players. Not so bad you might be thinking to yourself, let me explain what this spell does, first you have to wait untill the other players take their turns, then since its a spell any player may counterspell or other things to stop you. Then you have to roll a dice at 50% chance to succed, which after the end of my game my total percent of succeding was a whopping 12 % (in which i rolled 2 in particular over half the time) and then after all that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t all you get to do is take one life from the players, in which they can prevent, or heal back up (which there are a bunch of chances for players to be healed back to full, normally 4 lives). You might be thinking thinking thats not so bad, after 8-10 turns all the players should be dead, thats what I thought at first... but after 2 and a half hours, YES THATS ♥♥♥♥ING RIGHT, AFTER 2 AND A HALF MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING HOURS OF WATCHING THE AI TAKE THEIR TURNS AND ME DOING NOTHING BUT MINDLESSLY CASTING A SPELL AND LOSING THE DICE ROLL I ENDED UP LOSING THE ♥♥♥♥ING GAME. How in the ♥♥♥♥ing world of mathamatical averages could I lose that game you might be asking me? well, since the AI gets to take their turns, they just ran around the board building their stats up and healing every 4 or 5 turns. At 10 points in the game I had a single player 1 life from dying and lost every dice roll, I did not end up killing a single player during the course of my 3 and a half hour game, the odds of me losing 10 "coin flips" in a row is .09 percent by the way. and now to how i lost, after 3 and a half hours of playing this mindless god forsaken game, one of the players, a warrior, managed to turn me into a toad for 3 turns while being at 1 life for 6 turns, heal up and make his way up to the middle square in which he then had to battle me to kill me, at this point i was at 12 str with 2 modifier and a +4 str follower to his 11 str and +1 modifier. but when it came time to battle I realized that somehow during the course of my toadness the follower had vanished from the game, the AI then managed to beat me every single time, he rolled five 6's in a row by the way, I cant even do the math on that one. so my final thoughts on this ordeal, DO NOT ♥♥♥♥ING BUY THIS GAME, I wish I could get those hours of my life back but I cant, I will be haunted by this experience untill the day I die, if I ever am able to meet the creator of this game I will not be held liable for my actions toward that spawn of satan. ♥♥♥♥ this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												As someone who regularly brought Talisman (Second Edition) to Sega game nights and who no longer has a group to tabletop game with, my knee-jerk reaction to seeing a digital version available on Steam was one of irrepressible excitement - I didn't even bother reading any reviews, I just bought it immediately, so compelling was my nostalgic glee. Boy, what a dope I was. In fact, playing this now, I can't even imagine or remember why I liked it so much in the first place. To paraphrase another reviewer, all this game wants to do is make you lose. I thought perhaps one of the expansions might make it a little better, but here's how a list of the Reaper Expansion adventure cards reads: A robber gobsmacks you from behind - lose all gold; flash flood - if you have a mule, it dies a miserable, horrible death by drowning and you lose all your possessions; plague outbreak: all your followers become infected with bubos and die miserable, horrible deaths. And so on. Actual play with AI characters using the base set goes something like this: AI player 1: roll 5, land on a Forest; you encounter a frightening, powerful Wraith...who smiles at you and gives you an Amulet - no one can harm you with a spell, ever! AI player 2: roll a 3, land in the Crags; you found three gold! AI player 3: roll a 6, land on a Field; you encounter a fiery, angry dragon - you pit your Strength 3 Wizard against a giant Strength 7 reptile...and win! You: roll a 1, land on a Stream; your Strength 7 Troll encounters a Strength 2 Wolf...and loses! Lose 1 Life! Lose all Gold! Lose all will to live or ever play this effing game ever again! Basically, you spend hours and hours trying to beef up at least one trait so that you are strong enough to pass a duel with the Sentinel guarding the gate to the middle ring, then work your way through the middle ring (which is ten orders of difficulty harder than the outer ring was) to pass a trial which will allow you to get to the center of the board and engage in ultimate combat to see who is the winner. Unless someone has the Reverse Decision spell, which can reverse the outcome of any combat, making you start all over again from the beginning. There is very little fun to be found in this game, both by design and because of the clunky, unfriendly nature of the user interface (after seven hours, I STILL can't figure out how to make sure I get to use a particular item or a spell in combat). Also, it uses the first edition art, which is fussy, cluttered, and amateurish at best, and, "Hey, my little brother got a gold star in his art class, can he draw the Prophetess card?" at worst. MIGHT be fun for five seconds from a nostalgia standpoint, but, really...save your money - just look at the screen shots and video and say to yourself, "there but for the grace of gaming gods go I."

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												This is not a game so much as a hobby.  Every square on the board has different rules.  Every player has different rules.  There are four different decks of cards to draw from and of course each card drawn is unique.If you're thinking this is a role playing game where you might choose to pop over to that trader, stock up on items, then head over and kill that creature, you are going to have a bad time.  Game play is random.  Very random.  Strategy tends to be very broad and take hours to play out.  Mistakes are painful.  At its best, any one turn might have a 33% chance of something good happening, 7% bad and the other 60% of the time is just time spent.  Better maybe than real life but its hard to play with a goal of ever finishing.  And by something good I mean anything good.  You hardly ever get to do what you want.  Most often its just pragmatism: "choice a gives me slightly better odds at improving my lot than choice B, and choice C is suicide, so "A" it is."  Worst part is learning what effects what and where and when so you can tell the A's from the B's.You'd think computerizing the gameplay would at least make things faster but it absolutely does not.  Delays are built in automatically to attempt at giving all players a chance to respond to every action. And it's unforgiving.  You'll end up missing opportunities for counter moves because there arent always hard prompts when you could take action and no way to go back if you click wrong.  Wishing for a much freindlier interface like "You just took damage, would you like to cast that heal I see in your inventory?"  "You have a spell, which player would you like to have skip a turn?" or for Pete's sake "No one can effect gameplay until the next turn, why don't we skip ahead until then?" And please plaese please do something about the end game. "Autoplay to finish? Y/N" would shorten most games by hours.  * UPFDATE * (I found the house rules to shorten end game, makes it much better.  Why isnt that the standard?  Other way suuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuucks.  I get some of the appeal now, but still "No."))

content:
Posted: March 11
												To explain this game in one word: LuckGet lucky with the character you getGet lucky with your draws, your dice rolls, your enemies dice rollsOr you lose.This game has no skill in it. You get lucky with your rolls, And you win. Simple as that.But, only problem is, that is horrible game design.Now that wouldn't be as much of a problem if it where not for the card effects, namely those from the DLC.Bace set is good and fairly balenced, But once you add all the DLC in, things get a little bit... well... kids use steam. So I'm just going to say stupid. Lets look at the clasic set for a moment. There are some spells, and other effects, that allow you to teleport, but not in the inner regon.. Thats all fine and dandy. But then there are cards from some of the DLC cards that let you teleport. And thats it. They let you teleport up to the crown of command. The item that exist to end the game. There are no downsides to these teleports. You just use the card, and get a free win. It would be fine, if it wasen't so easy to get said items. No long is it this fun race to the middle, it is now a race to see who can get the teleport item first, and thus win the game. I unfortunately thought that this game would be as fun as the table top verson was, But I was wrong.Oh wait, I'm not done yet! This game is dead! No one plays this game anymore, So I suppose there is no reason to even write this revew, But you never know. The graphics are outdated, And the devs clearly don't want to improve them. There might be 2-3 open public games, so unless you have friends who also want to waste money on a dead videogame, or you did what I did and made the mistake of doing and buying the 4 pack, you have to fight horrible made AI that play overly aggressively, and will never try and progress the game. I can never finish a game because I tend to get too fustrated with the fact that an AI just attacked me for the 5th time in a row, and the game has gone on for about 40 minutes, or atleast it feels like, and there is nothing interesting that happens, making it imposobal to keep playing.

												I've played both the physical and the digital version of this game. Though I really like the physical game, I've come to hate the digital version. Why?1. number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												To preface, I have played hundreds of hours of the physical board game. This is one of those games that holds a special place in my heart and I bought this specifically so I could share it with my friends... The base ruleset is unplayable, unfun and without a workshop for mods to fix this, I will never recommend this game for anyone.In the board game, once someone has the crown of command, no more healing can occur. On THIS however, a troll with 6 gold can face tank the spell, run up to the top with nothing I can do but spend over a half hour (yes we counted) clicking "yes, continue" etc. On top of that, making the command spell have a 50% chance of success is just prolonging the game.I believe that adding a steam workshop to this game so you can customize rules, card sets and characters more easily would fix all my issues with this particular version. However as is, this is a literally waste of time and effort. Please games workshop give the community the chance to do what I know so many have done with your board game and let us make the game more fun as we see fit.

Over a LAN, maybe OK. But in my experience, especially if wireless communications are in the equation somewhere (cellular or WiFi), I seriously doubt there can be played a game between 2 people all the way through to the end as of the time I wrote this comment. For this reason, I cannot recommend it right now.

content:
Posted: January 18
												First off I love the boardgame. I love it so much I was actually going to spend the full $60 for the game and season pass. Thank god I didn't.The game is very unbalanced and not in your favor. I've played about 20 games now and every single time the AI wipes the floor with me. Every single time, I'll draw enemy cards that are stronger then me and lose 99% of the time. While the AI collects all the good adventure cards. There has been games by the end my strength and Craft will be pathetic like 6 strength and 5 craft while the AI by the end will have 12+ for both. Whenever I play as the Wizard I always get stuck with a counter spell and the AI never uses spells against me so I'm stuck. While the AI doesn't even have to be a wizard and will end up getting to use all the good spells. I've played the board game for years and there has been very few slim times it has ever worked out like this. Everything good happens to other players while I'm stuck getting nothing. And like I've said this has happened every single game. 20 out of 20 games. Also the AI is very stupid. There's too many things to list that the AI does that no one would ever do.So then you figure "Ok just don't play against the AI, play the game online against real players" Nope, not gonna happen. There's never anyone online to play with. So there goes that feature.I try to play by the rule and make all players including myself random. So far every single time the AI will get the Wizard and the Prophetess. So even the random feature is useless. Also the game isn't accurate. It will allow to have 2 of the same characters in the same game. So if I pick the Wizard or the Prophetess, the AI will also be one of them.There's only a very few reasons to buy the digital version and it's really scraping the bottom. Only in certain situations would this be a good buy. If you don't have or want to spend the price of the board game, but want to play with a couple of your friends and not playing against the unbalanced AI. Or if you're lazy and don't feel like breaking out the board game to play with your friends or to show people how the game works. Other then that, even at only $7 I feel ripped off. I'll say it again, thank god I did not buy the season pass!

You will roll constant 1s, 2s and 3s. Meaning the command spell is useless. Then over a period of 300 turns, the computer players will steal all your equipment, followers and dignity. And then somehow an npc who has inferior stats to you, will acquire a talisman and teleport from the outskirts of the board, directly to the centre of the board in a single turn.This mother fukcr has 1hp which he has had for OVER 300 TURNS, now is the time FOR HIM TO DIE. Product received for free
												This is an amazingly bad game.  I have never played the tabletop version but see no reason why this isn't a totally accurate port to pc.  The game is simply an endless sequence of random good things and bad things with not the slightest element of strategy.  If more good things happen to you than bad, you will buff your stats a bit and then it is off to the equally random quest for the killer command fire. Roll a few hundred more times and hope that the other players finally run out of lives (or that you do because you just want the pain to end). You could replicate this game for free by shuffling a deck of cards and, if you turn up a red card, move one square forward.  If you turn up a black one, either move one square backward or don't move at all.  When you turn up a Joker the 20th time you win the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 15 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
												Despite having spent many hours in this game I really can't recommend it.I've been playing Talisman for what feels like years and they weren't able to fix the many bugs of the game until now. If anything it feels more buggy than before. But the technical issues are only one part of the problem.To sum it up:-The algorythm for calculating the dices is plain broken. It can have several players rolling the exact same dices again and again-There are occasional crashes in the middle of an ongoing game that often make it unplayable, forcing every player to quit or start all over again-The game is highly exploitable. You can quit a running game and rejoin right away to undo the last move. Some people do it to prevent a move that would have killed them or brought them in a difficult situation. There are also character-based exploits like infinite supply to coins etc.On the plus side, it can be nice if everything is working properly for a change and if you get some decent players. There are many cards and items, lots of areas and expansions to explore... but it's a matter of luck whether or not you will be able to enjoy it.

content:
Posted: February 26
												I've tried with all myself to like this game. Heck, I've even played it for an absurd quantity of time (but not the ones you see in my profile, as I often open it during work and let it in the background) and bought two expansions.But no, the game planly sucks. It would be a really nice and good game, but let's be honest: there is no randomness in it, the game just choose a set of possible winners from the beginning and drive the events and the dices accordingly.You know who is going to win since the firts 6/10 turns, as it's pretty obvious who always get the best dice results and cards. Among those there is then a bit level of uncertainess of who will exactly win, but halfway of the game you know the winner.And this apply to you, too: the moment you start the game and EVERYTHING that happens to you is useless for, let's say 20 turns in a row, you know this is a game you will not win. Just quit, start another round, and try again.Useless like never getting a single enemy encounter for 20 turns, just always getting the exact dices number to move to all those area where you don't draw an event card, or getting a couple that are totally useless. Or you never getting the number you hope, and the IA getting ALWAYS the number you get, so you just go on for 5-6 turns in a row moving to a useless space and the IA getting the same exact number and landing every time in your space and fighting you and killing you because it ALWAYS get the good number even if they have like 20% of chance for it.And, no, it's not just a matter of bad luck: it's a matter of bad luck for a couple of games, but it's not when you play like tens of games and the pattern is always there. I'm sorry, but after having tried so many times, I don't buy it anymore, the game is scripted.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												If you're a masochist go ahead and buy this game.  I did so foolishly.  It has some great mechanics that are fun, but is crippled by extremely punishing RNG.  The game is a dice fest.  Everything, and I mean everything depends on your rolls.  After that you get to chose where you go, whether right or left and that's pretty much all.  Everything else is a no-brainer.  Kill the guy who is winning.  Steal the best items.  Rinse repeat.And how you win...*sigh*.  The goal is totally anti-climatic...the objective is basically a king of the hill thing where you kill off the other opponents to win.  It would be much better if you could just end the game there but since its so hard to even get there thanks to everything based on ♥♥♥♥♥♥ die rolls, they really have to make it so that someone has a chance to get to you while you do nothing but roll to try and hit everyone for a life point.  Talk about fun...not.  The slow drip of waiting for your turn even when you're not on the hill creates more stress than it should.Worst of all is the hateful RNG.  Yeah, I know that getting toaded is just part of the game but you may as well rage quit if your toaded because you are going to be hard pressed in getting everything you earned back while the rest of the players go ape $#*%!.  When you miss a turn or are crippled like the toad during a turn, it is maddening...and maddening doesn't make a fun game.If you just want to bs and drink beer and do something because you enjoy getting your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you by die rolls, this is the game for you. If you like playing slots this is the game for you.  If you like playing Hold'em this is not the game for you.  If you're simply looking for a strategic challenge in trying to win, this is not the game for you.  I'm unfortunately the later.Edit:  I'm editing my review because I couldn't get my refund so I kept trying this game and I noticed something:  How is I reroll the same number after a roll that is negative, 4 out of 5 times.   Each time it happens I quit the game and start over.  Am I really that unlucky or is it the game just trying to present me a challenge?  Either way, it is the most frustrating thing...even more so than getting bad teammates playing League of Legends.  Maybe I can trade this crap away.

content:
Posted: March 28
												4/10: This game is just silly, wildly-imbalanced nonsense. It's like the pay2win version of monopoly... for nerds.Typical pay2win, imbalanced garbage, the kind you would expect from GW. Here's some reasons why:It's based on a boardgame from like... the late 70s? It's a VERY old board game, at any rate. That should tell you A LOT. If you're all playing only the base game, and playing the same character (which will never happen), the game is about, 60% luck, 40% "skill" (knowledge of how to play).Now, If someone is playing an OP character, or any spell caster, for that matter, you can throw those percentages out the window. Then you will be 100% fu cked. That's because any spellcaster that refreshes spells can just spam spells until they (inevitably) win. Spellcasting is THAT advantageous.There's also PLENTY of pay2win OP characters that you can buy, which will be blatantly overpowered. And I haven't even tried the new Warhammer expansions (LOL... Warhammer characters, why not? Seamlessly fits into any game, right? Because GW knows they can milk a nerd OVER AND OVER AND OVER again).BECAUSE OMG SPESH MARINES *Every nerd on planet earth or gasms instantly*TL;DR: Typical pay2win garbage from GW, set in a chance-based board game that was originally created in the late 70's... Sound sh it enough for you?

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												If you're a fan of the board game then I'm sure you'll enjoy this.The graphics are okay, and reminiscent of the first edition of the board game.The AI is a bit iffy, but not terrible, although I suspect some of the RNG is a bit dodgy.I've played through a couple of times so far and the only frustration I had was trying to kill off an AI Warrior when I was at the Crown of Command. I was rolling 3s more often than not (you need 4,5 or 6 for the Crown to take a life from the other characters) and he was healing himself up at the Castle and at a random Healer card that had been drawn in the middle region. Took a *lot* of dice rolling before I eventually beat him. But he was massively overpowered in terms of Strength and yet was still not coming after me at the centre of the board. If he had he would have thrashed me. But he just kept bumbling around the middle region, losing lives, healing them ad nauseum.Hopefully some of the other endings will fix this frustration and make it a bit less RNG.Still recommended though.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												While I do definitely recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a board game to play or is a fan of Munchkin and is looking for an experience with more depth, this game definitely has a lot of issues as of this review that the developers need to work on. There are a lot of gamebreaking bugs that sneak in with every release, the game has a tendency to crash a lot with no real reason, and there is definitely function that could and probably should be added within the future such as more custom house rules or the ability to use characters from an expansion without using the whole expansion.That being said, I still like the game a lot. I would say it has the potential to be a lot better and while I do understand that the developers aren't a big group it doesn't mean it has to show.  This review might very well change to a more favorable one as the developers work on the game some more but I'm just letting people know that plan to get this game to expect a clunky experience to say the least, it's a diamond in the rough of a game.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Rough around the edges but the first time you achieve ultimate victory after backstabbing your way through all your friends, you might get hooked.It's a little bit like Mario Party, you'll often feel like random chance has a much larger impact than any choice you make. There is definitely strategy and a meta-game to it, but you'll occasionally find yourself glued in last place through no fault of your own. Mario Party-esque could be a good thing or a bad thing, up to you.There is a ton of DLC. Like, there are more characters for you to buy than there are to play in the standard version. Buying them is the only way to access them. Many of them seem MUCH more powerful than the default characters. It's the kind of setup you would expect from a F2P game. I can't imagine wanting to buy the game and ALSO buy a ton of minor additions piecemeal. I recommend the game, but I want you to know what you're in for.

												If you're a fan of the board game then I'm sure you'll enjoy this.The graphics are okay, and reminiscent of the first edition of the board game.The AI is a bit iffy, but not terrible, although I suspect some of the RNG is a bit dodgy.I've played through a couple of times so far and the only frustration I had was trying to kill off an AI Warrior when I was at the Crown of Command. I was rolling 3s more often than not (you need 4,5 or 6 for the Crown to take a life from the other characters) and he was healing himself up at the Castle and at a random Healer card that had been drawn in the middle region. Took a *lot* of dice rolling before I eventually beat him. But he was massively overpowered in terms of Strength and yet was still not coming after me at the centre of the board. If he had he would have thrashed me. But he just kept bumbling around the middle region, losing lives, healing them ad nauseum.Hopefully some of the other endings will fix this frustration and make it a bit less RNG.Still recommended though.
